The campaign in this game is an absolute masterpiece. Currently playing this in VR (Quest2) with Virtual Desktop (quest version with desktop streamer) in SBS mode and Reshade (Superdepth 3D)  and it's running great on a laptop with a RTX 3070 on ultra settings. 70-80fps with 125% render scale or 90-100 fps on 100% render scale. First time since I've had my VR headset to completely drain the battery in 1 go. The music score, stories, cinematics... This game has it all and I didn't even want to skip the cut scenes on this game as it's extremely well presented and compelling. Compared to this, BF2042 is an absolute joke and it's unbelievable how on earth they went from this to releasing BF2042.

Best of it all is you can pick this up on sale for $5 and it's by far the best $5 I ever spent on a game. Highly recommend it for the campaign alone but multiplayer is enjoyable as well.

Rarely has a game ever captured WW2 in such good spirit. WW2 is a huge event and not every aspect of it has been implemented in the game (like let's say the Russians). Great installment of the franchise. Compared to Battlefield 1 it isn't as enjoyable, but definitely fun and playable. I like some mechanics like calling in support via points, building fortifications, able to upgrade weapons and vehicles etc. Also compared to Battlefield 1 there aren't as much achievements. Managed to get them all without much grind, although some do require like 500k points and 100k per class, destroy 5 manned stationary weapons with a plane (managed to get it easy on Iwo Jima and Fjell 652), and so. Definitely would recommend to anyone who likes the Battlefield franchise or WW2 type games. Solid 8/10 <3

I don't think I'll ever personally forgive the BF fanbase for forsaking this game when it launched. This is probably my favorite Battlefield by far. From the fundamental mechanical enhancements like the infantry movement overhaul (once you climb a chest-high hurdle you can never go back to any other battlefield I'm tellin ya), to the feel and aesthetics of the game, it's a Battlefield game down to the very core.

You wanna know what Battlefield is? Queue up a Breakthrough match. Get on a real good one, and then you're on defense, and you're holding the last point, the enemy pushing hard as your entire team manages to hold on, keeping every tank back with artillery strikes, thousands falling as the medics scramble to keep them alive amidst walls of smoke, their reinforcements falling, and their tactics get more desperate, as they slowly crack an opening through your defenses, and Johan Soderqvist's epic soundtrack roars through, bringing tension and adrenaline rushing down your veins.

And then you manage. You and your comrades empty their reinforcements to none and win. Then Johan Soderqvist's "Triumph" plays, as you finally let go of the tension of the battle, and that sense of glory washes in like a tidal wave.

That right there? That's fucking Battlefield, man. It's the kinda feeling that gives you goosebumps when you remember it. You can't really put it into words, but those who felt it, know. This game deserved more. Much more.

First the price tag is horribly wrong wait for a sale or if you are into giving your money away and never own anything just get gamepass; The game won't launch unless you install the ea app and if that thing decides that you don't own the game, you NEED to REDOWNLOAD THE FUCKING game and then give admin privileges to the battlefield v exe and then if you are lucky it will launch.

Now to the review:
I am a battlefield veteran since the first one and this is not thaaaat bad but the teamwork is just lost, I can't say I completely like the game as yeah it scratches the old battlefield itch a bit but feels very far from what the core game is supposed to be, it has conquest, but you will have 0 fun when you notice the extreme and absurd amount of hackers.
What do they get from downloading software and to just get kills? Nothing but to ruin everyone elses game because dice and ea do not give a damn about you.
If you are lucky to find a server without hackers you will have a good time but as soon as one comes along the servers just go empty.
Is it better than the new bs like the state of halo and cod? Yes, yes it is, but the amount of hackers is just plain ridiculous.
It does look beautiful and you can get lost in the scenery but if you expect action like BF BAD COMPANY 2, BF3 OR BF4, no, it is a very very sad no.
It has a campaign...or something that exists there but nothing memorable.
What gets on my nerves is that yeah it's from 2018 but if you go to the original people still play it and feels more solid than what Battlefield has become.
It honestly hurts to leave a good review because the game will work only when it wants to do so during your first install, then the hackers, mostly kids jerking off to their power fantasy of just feeling better than anyone else because they can see you through walls or DDoS everyone and win with 170 ping 1st place while being lvl 1.
I am biased, I love battlefield, as in I could spend 8-12 hours straight playing the game...but not this one.
The weapons feel nice but again the damage system feels weird, someone can kill you from say the other side of a bridge with an assault rifle, valid, but if you shoot that person back with an anti tank rifle in the chest and you don't kill that guy that is very veeeery fucked up.
Again weapons feel good, not excellent, just good and it does not have as many weapons as there were in WWII, I think it has to be the smallest weapon roster in any battlefield.
I myself try to play it alone instead of in a squad like in previous titles because, like I've said, teamwork is veeeery rare.
I remember I played it on xbox one first and wondered how it would feel on pc and it's just weird man.

"Battlefield 5" is a first-person shooter created by EA DICE and released by Electronic Arts. It was released in 2018 and takes place during World War II. There are both single-player and multiplayer modes. The game is recognised for its rich graphics, massive battles, and realistic gameplay mechanics. I thought the game to be pretty engaging, especially given its depiction of World War II. The attention to detail in the armaments and settings was outstanding, recalling our conflicts in the Pacific theatre. However, there were several parts that did not fit with reality. The methods used and the depiction of some historical events were oversimplified, lacking the subtlety of real fighting. Furthermore, some of the equipment and technology demonstrated appeared overdone and unrealistic. Despite these discrepancies, I must admit that the gameplay itself was captivating, offering intense combat scenarios and strategic challenges. Overall, while I appreciate the effort put into Battlefield 5, I cannot say it fully satisfied my expectations of an authentic wartime experience.

A minimally worse version of Battlefield 1. I strongly recommend BOTH BF1 and BFV, if you're aiming to maximise your Battlefield experience. I tried BF4 but for some reason it's just not the same, presumably because on older BF games have a more experienced playerbase so things are much more difficult.

Well, here's some pros about BFV:

- The keybind system is AMAZING. This is the second game (First game being VALORANT) that actually bothered to make the keybind system FULLY FUNCTIONAL. What do I mean by that? Well, this means that if you want to bind multiple keybinds to the same key, YOU MOST LIKELY CAN. Here are some examples:

>>>Just like in VALORANT, I have my Reload and Inspect keys merged:
This just means that I have to reload before I can inspect my weapon. In most games, binds like these don't work. Good job DICE developers!

>>>I also have Sprint-Slide and Crouch Merged (without Sprint-Slide double-tap):
When you're sprinting, you can tap the crouch key ONCE for a slide, and you can hold it to go into a crouch after the slide. Admittedly, this isn't perfect, but you can still crouch-sprint with this for examle.

>>>I also have Sprint (Set to toggle), Auto-Sprint and Lean-Right merged into one key (My Left Alt):
Zero conflicts! Why? Simple. You can't lean while sprinting, and sprint/auto-sprint work very similarly, but with both bound to the same key, you can press the sprint key ONCE to start sprinting without having to hold any keys, or just use the sprint key like normal. Respectively, the lean left key you can bind anywhere to the left of your Left Alt, for example, CapsLock, LShift, CTRL, or even your Left Windows key. This is mostly up to preference and will depend on if you have any other particular keys that you like to have on one of these keys.

>>> There's the swap weapon / firing mode / zeroing distance keybind, I personally have it on my Middle Mouse Wheel Click, very convenient!

>>> By default, Jump/Vault/Parachute deploy are all merged together. This is great! 

>>> This one's probably crazy, but you can have your Interact, Enter/Exit Vehicle, Use Bandages keys all merged into one key! Pretty sure this works perfectly. On top of this, you MIGHT be able to do similar things with your Reload/Inspect key, however then a small issue will arise - if you were to merge reload with this interact key merge, you won't be able to reload inside/near vehicles, so exit/enter vehicle would have to be separate. This is where you could try binding it to your lean left key or something, THERE'S SO MANY POSSIBILITIES!

Maybe I have autism or something but the fact that you're able to essentially have Controller-level controls on a PC game is amazing to me. Presumably, all of this stuff works because of console. If so, don't be afraid to try out keybinds like STEADY SCOPE + ADS, something controller players do.

9/10 game. I can't really think of any cons outside of the occasional hackers (don't play official servers and you'll avoid them almost in entirety)

P.S yes all my pros are in regards to keybinds being so functional XD

The single player "campaigns" are nicely done (though there should be more) and I would recommend the game if it wasn't for the annoying bugs, e.g.: weapons sometimes become inoperable (and at one point I had 2 weapons but the game showed every one of them twice  - all of them inoperable - and I had to first pick up a different weapon before the glitch recovered). Similarly the mission script sometimes gets stuck and you then have to restart the whole mission in order for the story line to continue (e.g. happened in the Norway story when trying to progress into the "bunker" mission. Stood around in front of the bunker door and nothing happened since the game for some reason failed to register that I had reached the specified destination) Most annoyingly the damage detection logic sometimes stops to work, e.g. you head shot the same unit 5 times with the silenced sniper rifle (at fairly close range) and nothing happens (except for the unit starting to shoot back). You then have to walk away and come back for the glitch to recover. 

Sadly the stupidity of the game's AI is compensated by "aim bot" type cheating: It doesn't matter how often you circle around an AI opponent to sneak up on it. You may lie on your belly and as soon as your head peaks around the corner you get shot at (and hit) immediately. At the same time AI units are so stupid that you can snipe some unit that supposedly was in the middle of a conversation with the unit right next to it and the other unit will not show any reaction.

I was interested in the game primarily for its co-op multi-player. Unfortunately that feature is very underwhelming: There are only 3 different maps that are reused for a grand total of 6 missions.

Battlefield V, the latest installment in the acclaimed Battlefield franchise, takes players back to the tumultuous era of World War II. Developed by DICE and published by Electronic Arts, this highly anticipated title promised to deliver epic battles, stunning visuals, and innovative gameplay mechanics. As players don the uniforms of soldiers from various factions, they embark on a journey through some of the most iconic theaters of war. Let's dive deep into the trenches of Battlefield V and explore its every aspect.

Graphics and Visual Fidelity:
Visually, Battlefield V sets a new standard for the franchise. From the snowy landscapes of Norway to the sun-scorched deserts of North Africa, each environment is meticulously crafted and breathtakingly beautiful. The game's Frostbite engine truly shines, delivering stunningly realistic visuals, dynamic weather effects, and destructible environments that add a sense of chaos to every battle.

Character models are impressively detailed, with authentic uniforms, weapons, and equipment that evoke the spirit of the era. The attention to detail extends to every aspect of the game, from the intricate weapon animations to the immersive sound design that brings the battlefield to life.

Gameplay Mechanics and Immersion:
At its core, Battlefield V offers the signature large-scale warfare that the franchise is known for. Players engage in epic battles with up to 64 players, utilizing a diverse arsenal of weapons and vehicles to secure objectives and outmaneuver their opponents. The game introduces several new gameplay mechanics, such as the Fortifications system, which allows players to build defenses and fortify key positions on the battlefield.

The gunplay in Battlefield V is satisfyingly weighty and realistic, with each weapon handling differently and requiring skill and precision to master. The addition of Attrition mechanics adds a layer of strategy to gameplay, requiring players to scavenge for ammo and health supplies on the battlefield, further immersing them in the chaos of war.

The game's class system encourages teamwork and cooperation, with each class offering unique abilities and equipment that complement different playstyles. Whether you're providing support as a Medic, laying down suppressive fire as a Support, or leading the charge as an Assault, Battlefield V rewards players for working together to achieve victory.

Single-Player Campaign and War Stories:
In addition to its multiplayer mode, Battlefield V features a series of War Stories, standalone single-player missions that offer a more intimate look at the war from the perspective of different characters. While the stories themselves vary in quality, they provide a welcome change of pace from the frenetic multiplayer battles and showcase the human cost of war.

The War Stories feature impressive production values, with cinematic cutscenes, compelling storytelling, and memorable characters that tug at the heartstrings. While the campaign may be relatively short, it offers a poignant and immersive experience that adds depth to the overall narrative of the game.

Community and Support:
Since its release, Battlefield V has received regular updates and post-launch support from the developers, addressing player feedback and introducing new content and features. The game's community is active and engaged, with a dedicated player base that continues to support the game through forums, social media, and community events.

Conclusion:
Battlefield V is a triumph of immersive storytelling, stunning visuals, and exhilarating gameplay. With its epic battles, innovative mechanics, and attention to detail, it stands as a worthy addition to the Battlefield franchise. While it may not be without its flaws, the sheer scope and ambition of Battlefield V make it a must-play for fans of first-person shooters and military history alike. Whether you're storming the beaches of Normandy or duking it out in the streets of Rotterdam, Battlefield V delivers an unforgettable experience that captures the chaos and camaraderie of World War II.

## 10/10 Would bayonet charge a panzer again

**Here's the review:**

This game is basically historical reenactment with questionable fashion choices. You spend most of your time:

* **Dodging planes that fly lower than pigeons with vertigo.** Seriously, have these pilots ever heard of air traffic control?
* **Reviving your squadmates who think they're invincible because they have a katana.** News flash, katanas don't stop bullets, Karen.
* **Trying to decipher teammate chat that's a mix of 1337 speak and complaints about camping snipers.** I swear, some of these guys think they're in a ghillie suit convention.

**But hey, it's not all bad:**

* **The explosions are so realistic, I can practically smell the burnt toast.** 
* **The melee takedowns are brutal enough to make even PETA flinch.** Just don't try them in real life, unless you want to end up on a Darwin Award website.
* **The soundtrack is epic enough to make you feel like a war hero, even if you're just spending the entire match hiding in a ditch.**

**Overall:**

Battlefield V is like that crazy aunt at Thanksgiving dinner: loud, unpredictable, and occasionally throws something across the room. But you gotta admit, it's never boring.

**Would recommend?** Only if you enjoy controlled chaos, questionable history lessons, and the occasional existential crisis brought on by getting sniped by a grandma hiding behind a bush.

**P.S.** Don't forget to bring your running shoes. You'll need them to outrun all the grenades.

I was never going to buy this again originally for PC but curiosity and fondness for the Battlefield series prevailed, plus to also get away from BF2042 as much as possible!

As you might have seen from reviews and messages written by others, yes, this game will always have a cheater problem, and also the game will always feel like much more could have been done for it. But despite this BF5 is still a brilliant game, with plenty to make it stand out from the others. The movement, gunplay, how it looks, sounds...the immersion...its all there and its great. I could ramble on why its great the way it is but you are better off seeing and hearing it all yourself. Plus I know this little "review" of mine is going to be buried soon anyway so its not worth it! ;)

The player count for BF5 is still going strong, and it will be a sad day whenever it all shuts down, so if you decide to play it yourself? Make the most of it, for this might be the last Battlefield that is worth playing and remembering.

[h1]Going Back To World War 2[/h1]
Enter mankind’s greatest conflict across land, air, and sea with all gameplay content unlocked from the get-go. Choose from the complete arsenal of weapons, vehicles, and gadgets, and immerse yourself in the hard-fought battles of World War II.

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]💾Graphics[/td]
        [td]Battlefield V is still absolutely stunning! Ranging from destroyed environments that give the scale of what WW2 was all about, to the gorgeous beaches from the Pacific Theatre. The animations are incredible. The way the weapon sways around and how your character moves across the battlefield gives a great feeling of momentum. The character models and weapon designs all look amazing. Even the vehicles can look so stunning and intimidating. I mean this game uses the Frostbite engine, so it’s really hard to make this game look bad.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎮Gameplay[/td]
        [td]Battlefield V is like many other Battlefield games. It’s basically the same formula with some minor tweaks to make it somewhat different. Some of the changes would be the fortifications. Being able to create sandbags, machine gun nests, reinforce destroyed buildings, and much more. This is a pretty cool feature, but does require communication to be effective. Attrition is also a new feature here. Your health will no longer regenerate to 100%. This gives medics a much bigger role in the battlefield. You can also revive your squadmates even if you are not a medic (only people in your squad). Spotting is also different. Recon class can only spot players in the game effectively. I’m not sure how I feel about this change. I guess it gives snipers a bigger role and does give some much needed support. You also have your standard Battlefield features. You have the four classes (Assault, Medic, Support, Recon). You even have tanks, light vehicles, and airplanes. Many classes have their own pro’s and con’s and each have their own important role. I’d say it’s overall pretty well balanced. I do wish that the assault class anti tank weapons were a bit stronger, but besides that it’s balanced really well. You also have customization in this game for your character, weapons, and vehicles. It’s all pretty well done and gives you a good amount of progression, especially when trying to complete assignments to unlock unique skins and weapons.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]📜Story[/td]
        [td]I actually really liked the story in this game. It’s not long by any means, but really fun to go through. War Stories are captured really well in terms of storytelling. I didn’t really care about the first one, but the other three were solid. I won’t spoil them or talk much about them since they are really short. I will say that before and after each story, the game gives you some interesting information about the war, even stuff I didn’t even know about. It’s educational, and that actually surprised me. I think that made the stories much more enjoyable. Yes it’s really short, but you can tell the Devs put some time into them and had some passion behind it.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎭Multiplayer[/td]
        [td]The multiplayer is pretty good. During the time of this review, the player base is still pretty high and still seeing new players coming into the game. Cheaters are a huge issue in this game and can get absolutely annoying. Being shot through walls, everyone getting killed at once, aim bot, etc. It's a shame many garbage players need to cheat, but not much you can do about it. Best bet is to join Non-Officials servers if you want that to not be an issue. Apparently Official servers are plagued with cheaters. Besides that you should have no problems with the multiplayer during the time of this review. It’s still alive and well.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🕛Playtime[/td]
        [td]Playtime just depends on how much you enjoy this game. The story is probably around 6-8 hours to complete. You will spend most of your time in the multiplayer mode. It has an endless amount of replayability here. You have a ton of content here to mess with, for example great maps, many weapons to use, assignments to complete, etc.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎧Sound[/td]
        [td]Battlefield V has incredible sound design. The weapons sound impressive, hearing the airplanes pass by you is super immersive, and the overall ambiance is perfect! Battlefield always had good sound design, and this game does not disappoint! It’s immersive, intense, and really puts you into the experience.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❗Bugs❗[/td]
        [td]I haven’t really had many bugs in the multiplayer. I had some odd AI bugs in the story mode, but nothing too serious. It’s mainly just minor bugs in the story and multiplayer, so nothing worth bringing up. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔅Performance[/td]
        [td]Performance is amazing! I’m able to play on high settings with no problems. I do play on low online just to see a little better. The shadows can really make it hard to see in this game. I’d recommend turning off Ambient Occlusion so you can see so much better![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]✔️Pro’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Tons of customization
[*]Incredible sound design
[*]Amazing visuals & lighting
[*]Maps are really well designed
[*]Fantastic gunplay and movement
[*]Great amount of weapons and maps
[*]War Stories are pretty good and are educational
[*]Weapons & vehicles have a basic leveling system
[*]Different classes to play as (Assault, Medic, Support, Recon)
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❌Con’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Requires EA Play App
[*]Cheaters are a serious issue
[*]In-game store for cosmetics
[*]Some classes don’t feel balanced
[*]Could have had many more factions for online (France, Italy, Russia, etc)
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🏆Rating[/td]
        [td]7/10
I’d probably get this game on sale for 50%.
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔗Conclusion[/td]
        [td]Battlefield V is a fantastic Battlefield game! I would have rated it much higher if this game didn’t have a cheater and if the game felt more complete. I wish DICE added Russia, maybe even France and Italy as a faction. The game had so much promise. It kinda feels like Battlefront 2 where it just didn’t feel complete (no Star Wars Sequel and Prequel maps). For what it is, it’s a fantastic shooter that is still kicking hard after 6 years of release. I’d wait for a sale and give this game a try, especially if you love WW2 shooters.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

It is a beautiful game about the ugliness of war. It is similar to Battlefield 1 because there are different stories which are all set in the same war. All 4 stories/missions are well designed. The battle takes place in Sahara desert, Norwegian mountains, rural France and a large European city. I only played the game as Single Player. Some stories are much more impactful than others. 

The graphics are breathtaking even on High settings of GTX 1650. There was no crash during any of my sessions and no noticeable glitch. Frame rates were smooth, any drop in FPS was for only a few seconds and didn't impact gameplay experience. There is no dubbing of foreign language characters so sometimes I couldn't follow the subtitles when trying to kill the enemy or run away from their bullets and bombs.

I’ve never been a big fan of FPS games; however, this one has captured my attention.

The game itself is really good, but don’t expect the people playing it to be competitive and that kind of stuff. Sometimes, you’ll get frustrated with your teammates because they keep flocking to a single capture point or just outside a capture point.

The immersiveness is great, really great. This game is truly made to be fun and to be played as a squad/team, no lone wolf gameplay.

Making strategies to capture flags and being smarter than the enemy team feels great overall.

TL;DR

Great game, even for those who don’t like FPS like me 
Great immersiveness 
Great multiplayer experience (overall) 
Didn’t see many hackers (14.2h of gameplay)

Bad “team balancing” 
No ranked tiers 
High price (I’d only buy it when on sale)

Play it to have fun, not to try hard. Playing with friends is hilarious.

I'm thankful that I got this during a steam sale, only paying £3.59, because the game is mostly unplayable.

Downloading the bloatware dog$hit EA games launcher - what? - just to play the game that is downloaded and installed through steam. Then, when I view my other EA games, including Battlefield 1 & 4, it tells me to download them through steam.

I've logged into the EA account, but the game still refuses to connect to online services. I'm not using any sort of proxy or VPN. Not a big deal, you might think - but progress isn't saved apparently so every time I start the game up I've got to do the intro cutscenes.. it soon gets boring.

Then when it comes to the sections I could play - the War Stories - the AI on this game is dreadful. Enemies firing into nothing, and through solid objects, meanwhile my shots don't register if they're on a static MG.. was fun for the first playthrough but becomes tedious quickly.

Graphics are what I would expect from a game 10 years ago. Oddly, seems worse in comparison to Battlefield 1.

I'll uninstall and come back to this another time - it's not worth the 120GB file size on my SDD.

The only way I would recommend this is to buy it during a 80-90% off sale - and maintain a vain hope that the game is somewhat improved.

TL;DR Better than 2042 and still has more players than 2042, worth picking up if on sale. Don't waste money on 2042.

I always felt like this game got way more hate than it deserved. I didn't really start playing it until its Year 2 update, so I can't speak to it's quality before that, but it's always felt amazing to me. Smooth gunplay, polished animations, fantastic audio design and high attention to environmental detail and visual fidelity. I'm glad this game is more populated than 2042. 2042 is soulless mediocre slop, BFV will always be the superior Battlefield experience. It also has multiple single player campaigns unlike 2042. It's definitely worth picking up if on sale, which it is very often. Unfortunately, there is a cheater problem since DICE and EA have basically abandoned it to focus on 2042. But I personally don't see them very often so it doesn't seem as bad as everyone makes it out to be.

This is the worst Battlefield game I have ever played. It is nothing like Battlefield 3, Battlefield 1942, Battlefield 2, Battlefield 2142, Battlefield 4, Battlefield Hardline, Battlefield 1. The introduction screen was very laggy like call of duty modern warfare 2019 and call of duty cold war even when it was installed on a pcie gen 4 ssd. I can't believe the developers never fixed the bugs and problems with this game to make it a real Battlefield game. 

This game looks like and feels like a wannabe call of duty game because of the very misplaced perk system and different class specializations and extra gun aim down sight animations and movement animations and movement speed in the game.

Every time you try to complete an Assignment in this game, it doesn't register progress unless you specifically activate it to progress in it.

The voice acting and art design is very poor in this game as well. It feels like a robot talking with no enthusiasm or anything. Battlefield 4 and Battlefield 1 also had these same issues as well. The colors of the objectives look too light with gamma levels that are very difficult to see. The weapon icons are very over-simplified. All of the dog tags are very over simplified and almost all of them look the same.

This game brought back spectating from Battlefield 4 but also removed the server favorite option and started hiding the server browser options for joining games.

This game does not allow you to take out needed items like a healing medical pouch or healing medical box any time it is needed like in Battlefield 3, Battlefield 4, Battlefield Hardline, Battlefield 1, Battlefield 2, etc. Every action and equipment is context based so you are required to look at something in particular to change equipment and take out useful items to help the team in battle.

This is not a real Battlefield game. This game is too over-simplified to cater to the call of duty players that don't know how to operate a server browser to find a multiplayer server to play.

People may call this game historically inaccurate and make fun of it and its SP campaign and dubious uniforms. However, while they're all still very amusing, after playing this game for a full 10 hours in the first 2 days of owning it, I can confidently say that all that does not really matter. What does matter is how immersed you are and how the gun animation and handling is absolutely stellar. I recommend this game to people despite its historical inaccuracies. (One thing I would like to note though is that I really believe that guns should be limited to their theater so that Germans in Europe don't go around with Arisakas and Japanese soldiers don't randomly go around with STG44s for exmaple)

Same with every FPS these days: you're given a crappy weapon to fight against veterans with the best loadouts and on top of that the games are full of cheaters with wallhacks and aimbots - not only is there nothing you can do about this but the server admins are AWOL or useless and EA couldn't care less. Another useless purchase of an unplayable game. I bought this cheap on sale and still think I got ripped off. Oh well, another game to delete...

Speaking of the singleplayer campaigns,,, I don't believe that any Battlefield game must be absolutely historically accurate, but this, this monstrosity is but a crime against the memory of the WWII. 
The "heroes" portrayed and the events, are all messed up in such a way that it almost looks like DICE made them deliberately to be from ridiculous to outrageously insulting. 

Though "The Last Tiger" campaign has a pretty good story to it. It is rare to see the Wermacht soldiers to be humanized in the media. (Yet they were still too afraid to add swastikas to the game, due to modern German laws, I guess)

And the multiplayer is kinda mid. Cheaters on DICE servers, very few maps, almost all guns from the same cateregories feel nearly identical.

Battlefield V's biggest problem is the fact that it is not possible to rent servers, you can only play on DICE's servers. Now this might not seem like a big deal (or a problem at all), but DICE's servers do not have any system to kick (or vote kick) any bad actors from matches, which means that cheaters reign free in this game. Besides the usual cheats you see in FPS games (aimbots, wallhacks, etc.), cheaters can also execute a command that kills EVERYONE in the server in an instant. Despite the game having a premium price tag here on Steam, DICE seems to have zero interest on fixing or even mitigating this problem.

It's a shame because I really like this game. I actually think it's a lot better than Battlefield 1. The gameplay is just superior in every sense. Experiencing this game's gunplay, where actual skill is required and the bullets go where you aim unlike in BF1 felt like night and day. Suppression is effectively gone for good, so instead of having your accuracy obliterated, you'll only be spotted. The fortification system is also a great solution to the problem of losing cover when a building is destroyed. The reinforcements are also a genius way of incentivizing squad play. There's a lot less BS to deal with, such as fewer grenades, no gas grenades, no ridiculously overpowered battle pickups, no mortars. The game just feels more satisfying to play.

When you play BFV without a cheater in the server, it's a great experience. The problem is that this is a rare experience. For 50 dollars, this is deeply unacceptable. If you're going to get this game, make sure to get it at a steep discount.

SINGLE PLAYER here.
Bought it on a sale for single player because i wanted smth like the very first CoD. I remember those years i really fell into the stories and epic battles, etc. 
So i started Battlefield V and immediately i felt LOST. I have no idea what am i supposed to do. As soon as i shoot, everyone jumps on me and i die. I completed a few missions being stealthy, but the stealthy stuff i dont care for. Didnt get the war-like feeling, you are always alone, always running around, poking around, trying to find the way they want you to use to complete the mission. Always out of ammo, because for some reason those people dont die when shot, you need to pump em full of led for them to die. 
For, what apparently, is a stealth game, the shooting is clumsy, bullets go all over the place, dont kill anyone even when hit, ammo ends, then you look for another weapon but what made me feel the worst is the fact that many times i dont know what am i supposed to do. Repel tanks. Ok... How? With what? Yea, there are those machine guns and stuff but i cant remember where they were, so you just run around like a headless chicken from one anti-tank gun, to anti-aircraft gun, back and forth. Idk, really felt lost all the time and probably will not play again. I like the idea of more open-world, but a bit more explamantion on a mission, or a map, or some target points would be really needed.

I am not the most experienced player or gamer, so maybe its just me, but it just seems too "open world" if you give such brief explanation on missions and no tactic or target points on how am i supposed to go and where. Many times you start at one point, but only 1 out of 4 entrances in a base actually works out, so it feels like "ok lets try this door and see what happens... nope... ok, next time well go the other way". Seems like a chore. Not fun at all for me.

Good graphics tho. Good idea. Didnt like anything about the game sadly, uninstalled after a few missions.

"A Battlefield Triumph: Embracing Chaos and Victory"

Rating: ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

I recently dove into the immersive world of Battlefield 5, and what an exhilarating experience it has been! From the moment I stepped onto the battlefield, I was captivated by the stunning graphics and attention to detail that truly brought World War II to life.

The game's dynamic environments and realistic sound effects create an atmosphere that keeps you on the edge of your seat. The diverse landscapes, ranging from snow-covered mountains to dense urban areas, add an extra layer of strategy to the already intense gameplay.

One of the standout features for me was the extensive customization options. The ability to personalize my soldier, weapons, and vehicles allowed me to tailor my gameplay experience to suit my style. This level of customization not only enhances immersion but also adds a sense of ownership to the overall gaming experience.

Battlefield 5's commitment to historical accuracy is commendable. The attention to detail in recreating iconic battles and weapons of World War II is both educational and entertaining. It's clear that the developers put in the effort to balance authenticity with enjoyable gameplay, resulting in an experience that feels both respectful to history and engaging for players.

Teamwork plays a crucial role in Battlefield 5, and the squad-based mechanics encourage collaboration. Whether coordinating attacks or providing support, the sense of camaraderie forged on the battlefield adds a social element that elevates the overall enjoyment of the game.

Despite the chaos of war, the controls feel intuitive, and the learning curve is manageable. The inclusion of different game modes ensures that players of all skill levels can find something that suits their preferences, whether it's the strategic Grand Operations or the fast-paced Conquest.

In conclusion, Battlefield 5 is a triumph in the first-person shooter genre. Its combination of stunning visuals, historical authenticity, and engaging gameplay make it a standout title. If you're looking for an immersive and action-packed gaming experience that pays homage to history, Battlefield 5 is the game for you. Get ready to embrace the chaos and emerge victorious on the front lines!

First, I have around 400h on the EA launcher before I got it on steam. And as much I enjoy the gameplay, I can't recommend getting the game given the current issues with cheaters. 

I am really not someone that throws the word cheater around the moment someome has a good k/d or is doing some strange kills. That being said, I'm not exaggerating when I say I encounter a very obvious cheater (mostly aimbot & with vehicle spawn hacks) every couple of rounds at this point. In some cases, they literally make matches unplayable by frequently killing everyone with some sort of force redeploy cheat. 

There are ways to avoid them for the most part, by joining for community servers & avoid certain gamemmodes where they seem more frequent. Still, this game become the worst game when it comes to the cheater situation.

At this point, having to deal with cheaters on a daily bases is seriously impacting the amount of fun I have in this game. And since it has become obvious that EA is not interested in dealing with it them in their "older" games anymore, I cannot recommend anyone pumping more money into it.
The game is really nice. But amount of cheaters spoils all the fun. And reporting them is neither intuitive, convienent nor changes anything. I do not recommend until the problem will be fixed.

So...i enjoy shooters and war games and its immersion they place you in, BF4 was a the go to for close to tactical and all out war game, so i wanted to give those interested in Battlefield V and above, and veterans of BF4 and BF1 a straight honest review. Don't f****** waste your money, maybe if its 95% off, but even then your actually paying with mental health. This is game is garbage and recent reviewers troll you into getting it. Praises of this game are misleading. if you latency is not super low, don't bother. high possibility of cheaters, seeing as you get sniped with a auto behind a mound, or tank kills you from across the map. immersion sucks, (women?), no real forward momentum cause cover sucks. rural areas and urban are ok, but no suitable cover if your trying to sneak in some rocky terrain maps, aerial vehicles are still OP, automatics are broken at a distant. sniping is no point unless you got amazing latency and crack head reflexes. stalking is pointless. no hardvore mode for realism lovers of sort.

the developers have raped lovers and fans of the franchises since BF4. #metoo at this point of the BF life. dont give them your money until they bring something back similar to the winning titles. its seriously a drain on your mental health playing such a s*** game compared to BF1 and older. IF the servers of the BF1 and BF4 are still active invest in those, but beware the developers might sabotage the franchise further.

Battlefield™ 5 Campaign
Gameplay: 8/10
Story: 8/10
Graphics: 9/10
Environment: 7/10
Optimization: 8/10
Just like Battlefield 1, this game also focuses on war, and the impact of it on people. It feels like a cinematic movie, a million different things happening in just a contested point, or off in the distance on a flank fighting over a hill. This game is a step up from Battlefield 1 for sure, in every aspect.
Different stories, different perspectives and the impact of war that is portrayed from this game is just amazing. Very short campaign though, took me 6.3 hours to finish, but a good game nonetheless. The ending story was actually very depressing, realistic and outstanding.  Definitely succeeds to portray its message, so that’s a good thing.
8/10 from me.

TLDR: The game is great and alive but ONLY ON COMMUNITY SERVERS.
The game looks beautiful and sounds phenomenal. I cannot express how good the sound design in this was. Everything from a sound distance, weapons sound and OST is exceptional. 
The gameplay can give you mixed feelings though:
In the story mode, I only liked 3rd one for the exposition and 4th one for the narrative. But in general, the story mode is the one to skip.
Multiplayer is why people are playing this game. You have access to all weapons/vehicles/characters etc. No need to grind them and you only need to upgrade the weapons individually. 
Maps are great both visually and structurally. There are a lot of modes but in general conquest and breakthrough are the most populated in 2024. 
At first, I wanted to give a negative review despite praising the game. The main problems are unmoderated DICE servers which you should avoid at all costs because of the hackers. Literally unplayable but once you get to low KPM community servers experience is way better.

Battlefield 5 is a blast, no doubt about it. Realism? Check. Cool maps? Double-check. But selling out 50€ for it? Nah. (luckily i got it on sale).

If you're on the hunt for a military/war kinda game, Battlefield 5 is a good choice. But seriously, wait for a discount—50€ is pushing it. I'd say a sweet spot would be more like 25-30€ on Steam. They should know better.

And listen up, if you spot this game with a 40% off or more, go for it. It's a steal. The game's got me and my friends laughing and raging. Just watch out for those teammates who ghost you when you need a revive, even when the coast is clear (or so you think). Classic Battlefield move.

You can have lot  of dumb fun if you can buy this game at the price of a beer at 90% off. Yeah, there is zero historical accuracy on this, but playing as a nazi japanese woman with a M1 Garand and a PIAT can be pretty fun. The sheer amount of different weapons and vehicles that are difficulty to see in other WW2 games allows you to turn your eye away from the game's lack of authenticity. When you get into a squad where everybody are either clones of M. Bison from Street Fighter or nazi women, things get so absurd it becomes an authenticity of it's own.

Also, singleplayer is also pretty cool, missions don`t feel railroaded like in previous games, and that they added campaigns that you can play as Germans and Senegalese Tirailleurs.

Interesting things to praise:
- They ceased with the pay to win bullsht, you start multiplayer with all weapons and attachments unlocked.
- It's pretty cool that they give away the game for almost free for the sake of keeping the servers healthy. I have no problem finding multiple full servers in very late hours of the night. Activision could learn with this (they still charging full price for CoD WW2 which is one year older than this and has 1% of the server population). This game peaked at 120k players on release, and still getting 60k players every day. This is absolutely insane, it's impressive. I have never seen in my life a game retain 50% of its player base after one year, let alone after 6 years. I feel like EA really cares about this game. 

This game gives me hope that someday EA might improve as a company.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Battlefield V is a great game for several reasons. Firstly, it offers a unique multiplayer experience that is both challenging and rewarding. With a variety of maps and game modes to choose from, players can always find something new and exciting to explore. The game's graphics and sound design are also top-notch, immersing players in a realistic and thrilling world of war.

Another reason why Battlefield V is a great game is its attention to historical accuracy. From the weapons and vehicles used in the game to the uniforms worn by the soldiers, everything has been meticulously researched and recreated to provide players with an authentic World War II experience. This level of detail not only adds to the game's realism but also enhances the player's understanding and appreciation of history.

Finally, Battlefield V's single-player campaign is another standout feature of the game. Unlike many other first-person shooters, the campaign offers a compelling storyline that follows a group of soldiers as they fight their way through various battles and missions. The campaign is well-written, with memorable characters and plenty of action-packed set pieces that keep players engaged and invested in the story.

In conclusion, Battlefield V is a great game that offers a unique and immersive multiplayer experience, historical accuracy, and a compelling single-player campaign. Whether you're a fan of first-person shooters or just looking for an exciting and engaging game to play, Battlefield V is definitely worth checking out.

Battlefield V stands as a testament to the franchise's enduring legacy, delivering an unparalleled World War II gaming experience. Visually, the game is a masterpiece, with meticulously crafted environments that vividly capture the brutality and beauty of the era. Historical accuracy is a highlight, showcasing lesser-known theaters of war and providing an immersive journey through the conflicts that defined the 20th century.

The gameplay is both intense and strategic, fostering teamwork and coordination in large-scale battles. The addition of the War Stories single-player mode offers a compelling narrative-driven experience, further enriching the overall package. DICE's commitment to a live service model with Tides of War ensures a continuous stream of content, keeping the game dynamic and engaging.

Despite a somewhat turbulent start marked by bugs and balancing issues, DICE's responsiveness to player feedback has been commendable. Regular updates and patches have addressed concerns, polishing the gaming experience and solidifying Battlefield V's place as a top-tier title.

The sound design deserves special mention, with immersive audio elements that enhance the authenticity of the battlefield. The orchestral score complements the on-screen action, elevating the emotional impact of each encounter.

In conclusion, Battlefield V not only meets but exceeds the expectations set by its predecessors. With its captivating visuals, historical depth, engaging gameplay, and ongoing support, it establishes itself as a definitive World War II gaming experience. Whether you're a longtime fan or a newcomer to the series, Battlefield V is a triumph that sets a new standard for the genre.

Other than that it is a great game and with friends it is a blast!

I really like Battlefield 1, with it's story and with it's multiplayer. Despite cheaters it's still fun. So I was pretty hyped for trying out 5. And... I cannot. I can't recommend this game.

Dice... where to begin. Dice created a beautiful diamond. Really epic game. Battlefield 1. Story is cool, multiplayer is cool. I can't really say anything bad, aside these cheaters. Dedicated servers would solve it, but well, nobody cares about QoL addition, right? PC will always have cheaters, right? Consoles are better anyway, right? Yeah...

However then we got Battlefield 5. At the beginning I wasn't hyped. But recently I got interested. I bought the game this month. You know, it's been a while since BF5 came out, so I was almost sure all the bugs, glitches were fixed by now. At least most of them. But I was wrong.

At very least BF1 has story placed at the end of the war, while BF5... STG-44 in 1940? Tiger in german desert campaign? Like, come on. Dice, have you ever read any history book? Or is it some marketing move of "if we place Tiger in desert and StG-44 in 1940-1941, people will buy it, 100%"?
Then we have this Chauchat in french campaign... not like French didn't use their MAS smgs and french rifles, you can look up on wikipedia or military websites, it doesn't require paying. But, well, let's give them Chauchats and Lee Enfields. I don't deny that french soldiers didn't use these, but it would really make the campaign look better. French soldier with french weapon.

And then these bugs.
You swap to secondary weapon with mouse wheel, but since wheel is a bit overreactive, it swaps to primary immediately and it bugs out swapping, getting you stuck, you can't swap, can't shoot, until you change weapons from the ground. Why isn't it fixed, Dice? It's still in the game, even if it's in campaign. That is STILL your game.

Also shooting with sniper rifle into someone's head.
If there is a tree in like 5 cm next to enemy's head - no kill
If there's some other obstacle slightly covering soldier - no kill
And you can't even test, because if you fire, it's done, you alerted everyone!
And MGs are the worst of them all. Literally hitbox of these is like a concrete, rectangle shield covering entire soldier. No sniper rifle shot got them, I had to shoot with SMG or MG at them. I tried 20 times, in different scenarios. Yes, I've counted them. Headshot doesn't work. Shot in the chest doesn't work. Nothing. And shooting with sniper rifle is a real joy, but seems like Dice was like "Eh, Jimmy, let's go for a drink, you can work after some party!" and then Jimmy finished these hitboxes drunk as hell.

I don't mind the whole female part of campaign, I really like it. It's really cool, I don't care about these crying people "bcs it's a female story, boohoo". Grow some balls. Females in these campaigns in these games have bigger balls than most of these crybabies.
But one mission is bugged in Nordlys. After destroying two power stations, you gotta randezvous at the bridge, but then you find out your comrade is 800m away from you, so you come back only to see they are stuck on the desk. I don't know. Are Dice workers or developers underpaid or something? Should I even blame them? Maybe it's upper management that doesn't test their stuff and just blindly sends flawed games on the market. Mein Gott.

No, I will not recommend this game. It's not worth the price. Buy something else, something cooler, something actually fun. I guess I will come back to BF1. I already wasted too much time in this game.

The first mission where u can finally play freely - as the british guy sneaking up on the airfield - when u take a second primary weapon instead of the pistol, the game ignores all player inputs apart from walking - only way to resolve this is to restart from checkpoint!
This is the very first interaction of the player with the environment and right of the bat it doesnt work... SERIOUSLY? (on the second weapon from the guard it works - but when u walk back and take up ur original primary again as second primary, it bugs out again)
Its supposed to be a stealth mission - one bonus sideobjective is to reach the hangar undetected - so fine so good. SECOND side objective though is - blow up all explosive barrels - äh??? Really?
Also when a guard shoots at u it should alert the whole damn valley - surprise surprise it doesnt. U can start a major war at the airfield - the guards 300m away dont care - they r deaf. U can als run away and hide - 1 minute later no one cares anmyore...

I have been playing this game extensively since the Beta and I have to say even in 2023, 5 years after the game it is well worth the investment. You can tell when they were making and designing this game it was cared for and loved. The gun play and game mechanics are so fluid and rarely have glitches minus the occasionally lag stutter. 

I would go on to say that while this game is not historical, it makes a WW2 style game super fun. Probably the best one I have played so far in my life. I look forward to another developer who dedicates this much time again. Games like this aren't made like this anymore, at least not lately it seems. Sort of dark spot in gaming at the moment and this game has remained a classic for me for 5+ years strong now. Please consider giving this game a try and especially try the campaign. It is interesting and well done, and the challenges are extremely difficult which is frustrating and fun at the same time.

Good gameplay, it's fun, but understand how much you'll have to shoot someone to win in a Battlefield game if you're coming from any mil-sim type of game. Generally, I'd recommend something I enjoyed as much as this but there's a huge caveat mentioned below.

The progression/unlock system for the Steam version is broken. You're supposed to get coins to unlock things (new gear, new vehicles, and new specializations/upgrades for both) and at the end of the match it will say that you got it, or it will pop up mid-match, but you go back to your main screen and it's not there most of the time; also, as you progress you will get these unlocks less and less due it taking longer to level up or the challenges becoming more difficult, which really delays being able to unlock and be competitive with the people who have been playing longer and already have their setups worked out. I contacted their customer support about it and they gave me the run around and never helped and credited my account with what I screenshot that I was supposed to get but never received through the automated system in the game, but they were glad to take my money and that system works perfectly if you want to buy something in-game.

EA does not care to fix the progression/unlock problem in this game, it seems. This was a problem after Battlefield was brought back to Steam and I've not tried in a year or so but I noticed I never left a review stating this.

Edit on 11DEC2023: Yep, the progression system is still broken on the Steam version. Still a fun game, it's a shame really. Thankfully, I apparently just brought the unlock bundle when I was frustrated at some point and now it's not quite as much of a pain; I can just spend the points on upgrades rather than having to spend them on gear or a vehicle unlock AND THEN upgrades for what I've unlocked.

A pretty good WWII battlefield with a few huge caveats.. 

1) They didn't include the eastern front in any capacity which should be a crime. 
2) They don't include many late war weapons or vehicles which is an enormous missed opportunity for what could have been really fun an interesting content. 
3) They ended support for this game right as it was really starting to hit its stride so don't expect fixes for bugs or new content.
4) Rampant hacking occurs in this game and EA/DICE take no action to prevent it or ban suspected hackers. If you want to play without hackers, I suggest you go for the console version of the game.

Battlefield V : By Triple F

"Battlefield V", the second latest installment in the iconic Battlefield franchise, is a symphony of chaos and camaraderie that thrusts players into the tumultuous battlegrounds of World War II. Developed by DICE and published by Electronic Arts, this game stands as a testament to the series' dedication to delivering heart-pounding action, strategic depth, and an immersive historical experience.

From the moment you dive into the action, "Battlefield V" sweeps you off your feet with its stunning visuals and attention to detail. The environments are nothing short of breathtaking, capturing the diverse landscapes of WWII conflict zones in all their gritty glory. Whether you're dodging through the ruins of Rotterdam or sniping from the dense Norwegian forests, each location feels like a painstakingly crafted work of art.

But beyond the visual splendor lies a game-play experience that is as exhilarating as it is challenging. "Battlefield V" boasts a refined combat system that strikes a balance between accessibility and realism. The gun-play is crisp and satisfying, demanding both precision and adaptability. Every weapon feels unique, influencing your play-style and encouraging experimentation as you navigate through an arsenal of historically accurate firearms.

What truly sets "Battlefield V" apart is its commitment to teamwork. The game rewards cooperation and coordination in ways that few other titles achieve. Whether you're in a squad pushing towards an objective, calling out enemy positions, or providing vital support as a medic or engineer, the sense of interdependence is palpable. The "Squad Reinforcements" system adds another layer to this camaraderie, enabling squads to summon powerful assets like V-1 rockets or supply drops for a strategic edge.

Grand Operations, a hallmark of "Battlefield V", encapsulates the game's essence flawlessly. This multi-day mode strings together a series of connected battles, incorporating dynamic weather changes and resource management, all while narrating a gripping historical context. Each encounter feels consequential, making victory taste sweet and defeat genuinely disheartening. This mode stands as a pinnacle of game design, offering an epic narrative that unfolds through player actions.

The journey through "Battlefield V's" World War II is enriched by its single-player War Stories. While not exhaustive in number, these vignettes deliver emotional and thought-provoking tales that shed light on lesser-known aspects of the war. They immerse you in diverse perspectives, from the Norwegian resistance to a French colonial soldier's struggle for recognition. These stories remind us that the war was not a singular experience but a tapestry of stories waiting to be told.

However, Battlefield V is not without its minor battle scars. Some fans might miss the iconic narratives of previous Battlefield titles, and the initial content launch was lean compared to expectations. But DICE's commitment to regular updates and the introduction of the Tides of War system, providing a steady stream of new content, gradually assuaged these concerns.

Overall, "Battlefield V" is a triumph that melds historical authenticity with heart-pounding game-play. It captures the essence of World War II while delivering a modern gaming experience that rewards teamwork, strategy, and individual skill. Its breathtaking visuals, intense combat, and emphasis on camaraderie cement it as a worthy addition to the Battlefield legacy. Whether you're storming the beaches of Normandy, engaging in dogfights over the skies of Rotterdam, or battling in the shadow of a V-1 rocket, "Battlefield V" ensures that history's untold stories resonate through the chaos of war.

This game is special in a negative way.

The entire game is beautiful and aesthetically pleasing, but that's about it for the positives.

Apart from the very cringe and sjw trailer that tanked the game's launch, there are many other bad things about this game and very few good.

For the singleplayer, 4 war stories, all copied the formula of the last war story ''Nothing is Written'' from Battlefield 1.

''Nordlys'' being one of the prettiest but also the worst because it disrespectfully retold a real life operation to pander to a certain group of people, that don't even care about this type of game until it doesn't align with their stupid views.

Several Norwegians assisted by the british were sent to destroy the German heavy water factory and supply, they had to endure harsh conditions and were successful in the end, it was a very important operation in which they stopped the Germans from being able to produce weapons of mass destruction.

EA managed to turn this perfect opportunity for a CoD-style ''All Ghillied Up'' war story/campaign with more than 2 protagonists, into a lame disney-ahh story about a mother and daughter, single-handedly doing all of that and thwarting the Germans and their heavy water weapons.

If they wanted to include more female soldiers included in WW2 in the game, they had plenty of opportunities to do that with the Soviet front, because from what I recall they were the only ones who let women into war, as snipers.

Oh right, THE SOVIET FACTION DOESN'T EXIST IN BATTLEFIELD 5, A WW2 GAME.

The only two Axis factions are Germany and Japan, the only two Allied factions are America and Britain.
We just gonna ignore the French, the Italians and the fore-mentioned Soviets?
They literally had a campaign set in Norway and only like 2 snow maps exist in multiplayer, without any Nordic faction.
Same with the desert maps and no Italy.

Basically, the final war story ''The Last Tiger'' was the only decent story, even making me feel sorry for the driver and commander in the end.

As for the multiplayer, while it has a very bad anti-cheat system you can definitely have fun on CERTAIN maps.
Some other maps are just one side camping and destroying the other

So long as you have a tank and you are capable of having it be repaired a lot, the game will be fun, or if you just wanna mess around with friends or funny weapons such as the katana on Japanese maps.

Tanks are too easy to kill, like 2 soldiers with full anti-tank gear can destroy 1 tank and a half.
AA tanks are worthless when you're using them and are overpowered when you're in a plane.
Planes are aids and should be ashamed for existing.
Ships don't exist at all.

The downed system is stupid, annoying and repetitive.
I'd rather a button in settings that just automatically keeps me dead than let others be able to revive me from damage sustained by 2000 pounds of bombs or literal AP and HE tank shells.

Or just bring the revive system from BF1, which WASN'T aids.

The community is horrible, they can go to Hell.
Also I can't talk in chat for some unknown reason, thanks for that, EA.

Great game, lacking naval warfare unfortunately, unlike BF1942 - I thought that would have been an excellent addition.

The major issue with this game is the lack of campaign (really dropped the ball with that one.)

And the HACKERS. Good luck finding any multiplayer games without someone in an airplane, 1 tapping you in the head, running around with no scopes/bolt actions, 1 tapping you across the map, or people straight up "redeploying" the entire server. The anti-cheat seems to be non existent here, and is probably on purpose of EA's behalf. For this, I cannot recommend anyone to buy unless it's a $5 sale.

Disclaimer: Review will be based on Definitive Edition, EA Play includes Year 2 Edition

Battlefield V, at time of review, has reach player peak on Steam. It's currently the most popular WW2 shooter besides Hell Let Loose.

Campaign/War Stories are generic as usual for a Battlefield game (BF1 and BF3 being exceptions). No additional content with Year 2 or Definitive Edition.

Multiplayer isn't as amazing as previous Battlefield but at it's core is still Battlefield (Battlefield 2042 is a hero shooter, not a Battlefield game), from the weapons (still limited to WW2, a benefit and a detriment like BF1), to the maps (not bad) and the utility (elite skins make this confusing).

Definitive Edition includes all elite skins, shortcut kits, etc. so that will make getting into multiplayer way easier than before.

Would recommend only when on sale (at least 80%). Make Battlefield great again.

During the initial release of BF5 I decided not to purchase the game because there was quite a lot of controversy around political correctness. Recently the game was on sale for $4 and I thought it might be worth it just to mess around, but now I realize that I've completely wasted $4. 

The single player campaign was even more bluepilled than I could imagine. White male characters are either dumb or cold, and non-white characters are the ultimate victims trying their darnedest to survive white supremacy. The developers have forced players to watch cut scenes of the most cringe liberal propaganda wherein Africans are lauded as the saviors of the french war machine. Not to mention a teenage girl who single handedly kills a battalion of Germans while experiencing hypothermia. 

In the old days with battlefield 1942, the developers tried much harder to accurately portray the conditions of ww2. Men were developing the games and they thought ww2 was cool in itself. Now women are developing the games and they want to make ww2 like themselves, so they glorify it with foolishness. This is what ww2 would look like in the brain of an 11 year old girl. 

Online gameplay is okay but not as good as battlefield 1942, 2, or 2142. It's like a sad re-skin of battlefront 2

Don't buy this game even if it's on sale.

Shockingly bad game from a formerly good franchise. With a "campaign" that can be completed between hummingbird heartbeats and comically bad multiplayer, I had to do a triple take to make sure this was a DICE game.


To be fair this review is 5 years removed from the official launch so many of my issue stem from that fact. Such as its almost a guarantee, as a new player to this game, any lobby you join will be filled with sweatlords who have played nothing but this game since launch and know every spawn and angle, effectively making the learning curve vertical. Good luck learning and getting used to the goofy ass weapon handling.... in 50 hours. Additionally on the weapons, why do they all feel about as effective as a spit ball? I'll consistently get 3 headshots on someone and they'll still be fully functioning, effectively making people bullet sponges. This is most apparent with the support class which has been nerfed to shit and hollowed out into obsolesence.  Wanna get it close? good luck with the spread, wanna sit back and use an LMG as it is supposed to be used? You're sniper bait, really any class can outperform you at any range. Overall the game feels like its trying to be something it's not. Trying to appeal to a larger base than it can. 

Interesting addition is a chat filter that cannot be disabled and will censor not just swear words but other random words that are no no's. Sure you can incinerate people and blow them up with mines, but don't you DARE say crap or doodoo

At least its a good looking game and the sound design, while a step down from the previous entry, is still serviceable to the immersion.

Maybe buy it if it's on sale, like I did, but full price? You'd be better off buying a different Battlefield game.

From a person that mostly plays mil-sim shooters, this is my go to game when I'm not in the mood for ultra realism.

BF5 excels at that feeling of absolute chaotic warfare or a large scale, the sound design is TOP TIER, the visuals are stunning even 5 years after release this game is pure ear and eye candy, every battle is a spectacle to behold. 
The guns feel punchy and satisfying to shoot, the destruction is done so well that a picturesque town by the end of the match will be a ruined crater filled hellscape.

BF5 is very very rare EA W, (DICE carried hard) IMO it is by far the best battlefield we've gotten so far, it mixes all the best parts of BF1 and previous battlefields and puts it all into a WW2 package that is a joy to play.

The game is currently suffering from a cheater problem but its easy to avoid by just switching servers don't let that stop you from experiencing this gem.
I Recommend this game 1000000000% the and graphics and gun play, gameplay is awesome + it has a great campaign!

I love almost everything about this game; the environment, the destruction, the beautiful look and feel of the maps, and the amazing movement. You have your casual run, jump, crouch, and prone, but added into the mix are crouch running to stay covered in shallow trenches, rolls that you can use to break your fall from tall heights, and sliding, all of which flows incredibly well. I clocked over six hundred hours on console, and when I saw this game was on sale for only a few bucks on Steam, I couldn't resist picking it up again.
However, the biggest gripe that I have with the game that immediately became apparent as I started playing again is the TTK. It feels a lot like COD at certain points with how fast you get gunned down once your opponent aims faster than you, and I wouldn't have such a problem with it if dying wasn't such a coin toss between being very punishing or a minor inconvenience depending on your vicinity to a competent medic. Assuming you're not (which is about 60% of the time), you have to wait to bleed out, then wait in the menu, then spawn on a point that deploys you half a kilometer behind it if it's under attack. If you're on a team with tons of medics, dying is a non-issue as long as you stay together and don't get ambushed, but if there's only a few of them, you're doing that whole process over and over again. Spawn, run at objective, die by Type 2A, wait, repeat.
When you have a good team and it's a tug of war between some really decent players though, the game really shines. I've had some super fun moments doing guerilla raids on enemy objectives with the squads I've been in with everyone playing their roles and keeping each other in the fight when one would go down. I find that the best squad cohesion happens when one of us has a tank, using it as a source of cover and keeping it healed when it gets into fights with other ones. Once you work together with your squad, the game transforms from a dying and waiting simulator to an epic fight for survival. What really sucks about it though is that, despite how much emphasis there is on squad play in this game, people typically just use members of them as spawn points.
I really want to recommend this game, but with how imbalanced the systems in it are, the community's love for abusing broken weapons, and the fact that the devs just gave up on it and dropped it in the most pathetic failure of a live service I've ever seen, I can't. It's still more fun than 2042 and more active than Battlefield 1 though, so if you've got an itch for a decent World War 2 shooter, top notch environmental destruction, and some buddies to play with, go for it.

The hype was real back in 2018.  

Battlefield 1942 came out long ago, the wait was finally over for veterans of the franchise who have been craving a new WW2 Battlefield game.

It had a rocky launch. 

It was the first "Live Service" Battlefield game to come out. It was also released back when Dice had shown their "true" colors as a company, and I don't mean that as a compliment. Everything from cut content, to microtransactions, woke censorship, bugs, you name it. 

Development progress was extremely slow. I'm still baffled they managed to release the Pacific Theater, which was amazing. Unfortunately, thats where development had ended for Battlefield V. 

Despite all that, graphics are good, sound design is good, features the best FPS mechanics in the series, map design is good, gameplay is good, destruction is good, and had all the bits and bobs for settings to customize.

I've read reviews that's say there are lots of hackers?
I have around 350-400 hours off steam for this game,  and have only encountered 1 or 2 since launch. You can't really run and gun very well in this game. Vets who know the maps, the tactics and the guns, can steam roll entire teams of newbies with ease. That's where I believe most of the concerns are coming from about hackers. Just get some hours under your belt, play slower, and you'll be fine.

If only Dice had continued thier work and gave us the Russian Front, I would have been satisfied as a long time fan.

Its still a banger game and is one of, if not, my favorite Battlefield game to date.

Considering i bought this for 2.5$, Its definitely worth it for the grand multiplayer experience. Even the single player campaign, although short is surprisingly well made with relatable characters. Its graphically spectacular to the point where i sometimes stop in the middle of multiplayer to stare at the jaw dropping imagery in front of me. The Gunplay felt fine, Vehicles like tanks and aircraft are fun to pilot especially with teammates and the sheer chaos they introduce into the battlefield keeps the games feeling fresh every time.

All that said the game does have issues, mainly with campers hiding out in some corner with sniper rifles shooting you dead from halfway across the map. I wish they introduced a kick mechanism like the newer CoD games to incentivize moving around and prevent camping. It gets even worse when the campers are also hacking, shooting you dead through walls from impossible angles. The optimization of the game is also  subpar and if your'e on older hardware with a weaker CPU or not enough Ram, you will experience frame rate issues and stuttering, especially on the 64 player multiplayer games.

I paid $4 for this game on a black friday deal.

I got 23.2 hours of entertainment out of the single player campaign on hard running through them one time. I did not get all the challenges associated with the campaign, so if I go back for that I'm thinking maybe 35 hours of single player.

Running on a 3.5GH i9 with a GTX 3080 

I have not played any multiplayer, so add the infinite replay ability of that if it isn't a hackers paradise (not holding my breath).
FYI - The single player is in the same theme of the BF1 campaign, different charaers in different scenarios with different goals.

Graphics - 7.5 Good - The game played smooth, but cut scenes gave me some stutter, I assume from rendering issues. Made the story less than it could have been.
Sound - 8 Very good - If you have your headphones on right enemies are right where they sound like they are.
Scenarios - 8.5 - great - The only part of single player that was a let down was the last scenario in the Tiger tank.

[h1][b]Short review of Battlefield™ V[/b][/h1]

[h2][b]+[/b][/h2]

[b]• Beautiful graphics
• War atmosphere
• Excellent shooting mechanics
• Good old-fashioned fighting classes (Assault, Medic, Support and Sniper)
• Great optimization
• Lot of maps
• Multiple weapons
• Weapon customization
• Map Development Detail
• Soundtrack
• Low TTK (Time to kill)[/b]

[h2][b]-[/b][/h2]

[b]• Sometimes you get cheaters
• Disregard for history
• Very many players with maximum level and playing against them is difficult[/b]

[h2][b]Result[/b][/h2]
[b]Battlefield™ V is a very good shooter, and is the last Battlefield to feature a classic class-of-fighters system, and the battle soundtrack and constant explosions are more war-like than Battlefield™ 2042. At 92% discount is the best choice to buy. I recommend this game.[/b]

After the turbulent launch that had me questioning my life choices, Battlefield 2042 has transformed into the game I've been longing for, thanks to the Season 6 update! The developers have hit the sweet spot between chaos and strategy, turning what felt like a chaotic battlefield into a tactical masterpiece. It's like they've sprinkled magic pixie dust over the game, and now it's finally living up to its futuristic promise.

First off, kudos to the team for the visual feast that is the new maps. The vibrant landscapes and attention to detail are so captivating that I often find myself taking a moment to appreciate the view—right before being obliterated by a well-placed sniper shot, of course. The Season 6 update injected fresh life into the game, introducing exciting weapons and gadgets that make every firefight a unique experience.

While I'm loving the direction the game is heading, there are still a couple of glitches that stubbornly refuse to retire. Occasionally, I find myself glitching through a wall like a ghost trying to haunt the battlefield, and the occasional server hiccups can make me want to pull my hair out. It's like taking one step forward and half a step back, but the overall journey is still worth the occasional hiccup.

In conclusion, Battlefield 2042 has evolved from a rocky start into a game that now makes me cancel weekend plans just to dive into its immersive chaos. The Season 6 update has injected life into the veins of this title, turning it into the futuristic epic it was meant to be. There may be a few glitches in the matrix, but the sheer joy of playing overshadows these occasional bumps in the digital road. Keep it up, DICE—you've turned this skeptic into a Battlefield believer!
