I will admit I am in the fringe minority in that I don't like Multiplayer and buy games like Battlefield and CoD strictly for single player campaigns and stuff like bot matches and instant action.
That said, Battlefield V has one of the saddest campaigns out there.
The very first mission makes the campaign feel like it'll have big 'battlefield moments' and this never happens in play.
Campaign 1 was by far the weakest being just very weak stealth sections with a challenge that made me realize the keyboard controls for the planes is probably the worst KB+M flight controls ever made.
Campaign 2's missions dragged almost as much as Campaign 1's and makes me wonder why they decided to front load two campaigns of generic stealth segments and wide open three objective maps.
Campaign 3 was actually enjoyable and felt like an actual battlefield campaign.
Campaign 4 was the most interesting deciding to be nearly strictly in a tank with only two brief on foot section. It also had the most interesting character dynamics and moral questions raised. Had the previous three campaigns been remade to that quality it probably would have lead to a better experience.
I got it on sale for 5.86 CDN and honestly I think the campaign is just BARELY worth that price.
I've played bargain bin FPS games that gripped me more than BFV's campaign did.

I love it!

Let's get it started.

+Incredibly beautiful. The game looks amazing, I'm not sure I've ever seen anything like this in a shooter. I had a very strong desire to set the settings to ultra and just walk around the maps on empty servers to look at this beauty. The developers' attention to detail has always been at a high level.
+Specializations. The mechanics have been updated and the perks are now immediately available, but the game is still most effective in a squad, which is a plus as it's fun. The classes have been redesigned and are now better and more balanced.
+Minor new mechanics and reworked old mechanics. First aid kits, ammo, supply boxes, the ability to revive a squad member, and rewards for squad points are done very well and fit into the gameplay. The absence of an actual wallhack when spotting, as in BF4, is also a big plus.
+Official servers. No more sh!tty rules from stupid admins, no more permanent bans for politely telling the admins why their rules are sh!tty. It's amazing that there are no class restrictions, no nukes, no rebalancing and other idiotic things. We can just play the way we like.
=Squad. Playing in a squad with friends is just as damn fun and highly effective as playing with random people in your squad is boring and unproductive.
+/-Recon class. This has become much more useful. You can now spot enemies in an area with the Flare Gun and when hit. Why isn't this a real plus? The fact is that the Battlefield games have a recon class and no sniper class, which does not give us the opportunity to get the classic sniper experience. Killсam will always shows your position when you kill somebody and your rifle will never kill with a single shot on a body.
+/-Maps. As I said earlier, appearance is amazing. But there are few of them and many of them are unbalanced and boring.
+/-HUD settings. It's just as customizable as in BF4, but now we're finally spared from the disgusting battlelog, and we can directly join a friend without any problems. This should be in games by default so it is not a really plus and in this case DICE fixed their mistakes.
-Cheaters. The official servers have only one problem - the lack of human moderation and/or a kick voting system. The anti-cheat system does not work here at all, and a couple of years ago EA initiated the free giveaway of an unlimited number of copies of the game through Amazon. As a result, even if the cheaters is banned, they can easily buy a new account on third-party sites for a very small price, or perhaps they have already created a dozen accounts for himself during that giveaway. This is a huge problem, in about half of all matches you will encounter a cheater. If you suspect cheating, but you are not sure whether to send a report, I recommend checking the player's nickname on the bfvhackers website.
-Balance. Unfortunately, traditionally everything is very bad. Incredible high rate of fire + good control of some types of weapons (Type 2A, etc.), automatic shotguns (several oneshots per second), DMR, prone playstyle with a machine gun - huge advantages. The aircraft have been made even more powerful and you will die from them a lot, the situation is much worse than in BF4, because here they mainly attack infantry. DICE don't know what balance is and this game is no exception. The biggest cons.
-Gadget keys. At critical moments, they may simply not work literally up to a minute. This doesn't happen often, but it's very frustrating because the game simply won't let you use your first kit.
-Unlocking. Not only are newcomers forced to compete with more experienced players, but they don’t even have specializations for weapons from the start and they have to unlock them. The stupidest trend and I have no idea why all shooters have this annoying thing.
-No test range. BF4 had a great test range where you could set up settings and adjust your classes. The test range in BF5 is terrible. You can't set up classes and test them, and there aren't enough interactions to fine-tune HUD and other things.
-Community. It's disgusting here too. The developers deliberately added imbalanced weapons to retain the casual audience, but the garbage community here plays almost with such weapons only.
-Censorship. EA suppresses free speech all the time but this is truly a new level, I have never seen anything like this. Now the chat has a censor and some of your words will be replaced with "***". FC U EA. You are trash.
-Support. DICE and EA don't care about their products. There is no chance that any of the above will be fixed.

I must admit that this is quite an entertaining product. If you have even one person willing to share multiplayer gameplay with you, I highly recommend it. BF5 is vastly superior to BF4 in almost every way. But the fact is that both of these games have common cons that are most important to the gameplay. A good gaming experience is a consequence of playing cooperatively with friends, and not the merit of the game itself. Therefore, playing alone is very uninteresting, boring and annoying due to the imbalance.

Verdict. Objectively the game is very bad. Terrible balance and community, lots of cheaters - are the main cons that make the game unplayable. However, playing in a squad can keep you here for a while. I'd like the game to get a few patches, but since no one cares about it, I wish it dead.

The "Not Recommended" was given because the game doesn't deserve the 70% positive reviews it has on Steam. I think the % should be <40.

p.s. The review has been updated as I have changed my mind on some aspects of the game.

This game is amazing, although it has a few flaws. I personally recommend this game, 

𝐏𝐑𝐎𝐒:
1. Amazing graphics
2. Destructible walls and barriers
3. You can build sandbag walls, turrets and other heavy weapons as a support, barbed wire, and a few more.
4. Amazing guns
5. Good customizations for the guns
6. Great variety of vehicles for the Japanese, American, British, and German sides
7. Destruction is very rarely randomized by AI. Most of what you see is made by a player and looks randomized. The only randomized destruction you'll see it outside of the battlefield which you barely notice.
8. Easter eggs!
9. Revival mechanics that allow you to ask for help or skip the revive. Unlike Battlefield 1, you aren't just a limp corpse, you actually have an animation and can look around with your hand outstretched while asking for help. You also have different lines depending on whether you are fighting for the Germans, British, American, or Japanese.

Killсam will always shows your position when you kill somebody and your rifle will never kill with a single shot on a body.
+/-Maps. As I said earlier, appearance is amazing. But there are few of them and many of them are unbalanced and boring.
+/-HUD settings. It's just as customizable as in BF4, but now we're finally spared from the disgusting battlelog, and we can directly join a friend without any problems. This should be in games by default so it is not a really plus and in this case DICE fixed their mistakes.
-Cheaters. The official servers have only one problem - the lack of human moderation and/or a kick voting system. The anti-cheat system does not work here at all, and a couple of years ago EA initiated the free giveaway of an unlimited number of copies of the game through Amazon. As a result, even if the cheaters is banned, they can easily buy a new account on third-party sites for a very small price, or perhaps they have already created a dozen accounts for himself during that giveaway. This is a huge problem, in about half of all matches you will encounter a cheater. If you suspect cheating, but you are not sure whether to send a report, I recommend checking the player's nickname on the bfvhackers website.
-Balance. Unfortunately, traditionally everything is very bad. Incredible high rate of fire + good control of some types of weapons (Type 2A, etc.), automatic shotguns (several oneshots per second), DMR, prone playstyle with a machine gun - huge advantages. The aircraft have been made even more powerful and you will die from them a lot, the situation is much worse than in BF4, because here they mainly attack infantry. DICE don't know what balance is and this game is no exception. The biggest cons.
-Gadget keys. At critical moments, they may simply not work literally up to a minute. This doesn't happen often, but it's very frustrating because the game simply won't let you use your first kit.
-Unlocking. Not only are newcomers forced to compete with more experienced players, but they don’t even have specializations for weapons from the start and they have to unlock them. The stupidest trend and I have no idea why all shooters have this annoying thing.
-No test range. BF4 had a great test range where you could set up settings and adjust your classes. The test range in BF5 is terrible. You can't set up classes and test them, and there aren't enough interactions to fine-tune HUD and other things.
-Community. It's disgusting here too. The developers deliberately added imbalanced weapons to retain the casual audience, but the garbage community here plays almost with such weapons only.
-Censorship. EA suppresses free speech all the time but this is truly a new level, I have never seen anything like this. Now the chat has a censor and some of your words will be replaced with "***". FC U EA. You are trash.
-Support. DICE and EA don't care about their products. There is no chance that any of the above will be fixed.

I must admit that this is quite an entertaining product. If you have even one person willing to share multiplayer gameplay with you, I highly recommend it. BF5 is vastly superior to BF4 in almost every way. But the fact is that both of these games have common cons that are most important to the gameplay. A good gaming experience is a consequence of playing cooperatively with friends, and not the merit of the game itself. Therefore, playing alone is very uninteresting, boring and annoying due to the imbalance.

Verdict. Objectively the game is very bad. Terrible balance and community, lots of cheaters - are the main cons that make the game unplayable. However, playing in a squad can keep you here for a while. I'd like the game to get a few patches, but since no one cares about it, I wish it dead.

The "Not Recommended" was given because the game doesn't deserve the 70% positive reviews it has on Steam. I think the % should be <40.

Battlefield™ V is an immersive and exhilarating gaming experience that truly transports players into the heart of historic conflicts. From the detailed landscapes to the intense, adrenaline-pumping action, this game captivates from the moment you start playing.

One of the most impressive aspects of Battlefield™ V is its attention to detail. The graphics are stunning, bringing to life the battlegrounds of World War II with an incredible level of realism. Whether you're navigating through dense forests, storming through war-torn cities, or engaging in epic battles across vast landscapes, the visual fidelity is nothing short of breathtaking.

The gameplay itself is where Battlefield™ V truly shines. The combination of infantry combat, vehicular warfare, and destructible environments creates an incredibly dynamic and immersive experience. Every match feels different, offering a variety of strategic options and approaches to achieve victory. Whether you prefer the fast-paced chaos of close-quarter combat or the tactical maneuvering required for long-range engagements, there's something for every type of player.

The attention to historical accuracy is commendable, with authentic weaponry, vehicles, and environments that truly transport players back to the era. The game also introduces new gameplay mechanics, such as fortifications and attrition, which add depth and realism to the overall experience.

Moreover, the game's multiplayer mode is where Battlefield™ V truly excels. The large-scale battles with up to 64 players create an intense and exhilarating atmosphere that keeps you on the edge of your seat. The teamwork and coordination required to secure objectives and emerge victorious foster a sense of camaraderie among players, making each victory feel earned and rewarding.

The post-launch support and updates for Battlefield™ V have been impressive, continuously introducing new content, maps, and modes, keeping the gameplay fresh and exciting for veterans and newcomers alike.

In conclusion, Battlefield™ V is a masterpiece that successfully combines stunning visuals, engaging gameplay, historical authenticity, and a thriving community. It's a must-play for any fan of first-person shooters or anyone looking for an immersive gaming experience that delivers on all fronts.

AMAZING GAME...!!!

I have about 500+ hours on PS with this game, before I 'migrated' over to PC. 

If anything, I think this games tale is unfortunate. It had some neat innovation regarding gameplay, like Squad-leader reinforcements and that infamous V-1, movement mechanics that not many people know about, like pressing crouch before hitting the ground when falling a moderate distance to do a combat roll to nullify fall damage, the fact that if you string sniper headshots, your characters starts counting past the third kill, the interesting weapon upgrade tree and tons more, yet it still was mostly a fart in the wind.

The bar was already high in the wake of BF1 with this game, and due to terrible marketing among other blatant factors, they shit the bed since that infamous day the horrid trailer released.
People on twitter can twist it any way they like, the 'diversity' inclusion of women in ALL factions is more insulting to the role of women during the Second World war then totally leaving them out.

They could have had women during a 1945 Germany as Volksturm or the multiple woman battalions the Red Army had, even maybe be creative with a Resistance faction (and not just the French).
Speaking of which, the fact they cut out the Red Army in development when they ceased game support, (Evident by the fact that they once accidentally had an experimental soviet machine gun in the shooting range, the LAD, 2 years ago) was the biggest missed opportunity ever. Especially because the dedicated '''''''''''DEVELOPMENT''''''''''' time for BF2042 was practically for nothing.

How fun would it have been to run around with a PPsh-41 in this game? Blast people with a T-34? Play with a Panther on the Wehrmacht on a map like Kursk? Have one of the Squad-leader reinforcements be a Nebelwerfer/Katyusha strike? Have the Special tank for the soviets be a KV-2? Dogfight Bf109s with Yak-9s? Have the Red Army scream their iconic war cry when they advance as attackers during Breakthrough? A Battle of Stalingrad? Moscow? An Operation with these? Maybe even lesser known fronts like the Lapland Pocket or the Siege of Königsberg? Even the Battle of Berlin with King Tigers and IS-2s? It could have been the greatest shit ever!

Instead we got a launch with stupid politics, a director that said a line of utter meme worthy proportions, who got himself fired within two months of launch, a hacker problem of mythical scale with bugger all offical regulation, the LATE inclusion of community servers and the IDIOTIC decision to make them free, inclusion of Women in the Wehrmacht, the US Army, the Royal Army as well as the the Imperial Japanese Army, that is historically inaccurate and during a time when gamers were getting sick of identity-politics and a later Battlefield game that only recently got player-numbers back because they put the game down to 10 bucks. 

Let this be a cautionary tale and hope for better things. Thanks for coming to my TET talk.

I truly believe that the Battlefield franchise was a criminally underrated series based on what it had to offer in comparison to other games and franchise of this genre. Battlefield V might have been the last truly great entry in the franchise and I firmly believe it is one of, if not the best. Battlefield V may not have been the most historically accurate game, but the gameplay, the maps and especially the audio made it extremely difficult not to be immersed in the setting the game takes place in. The game only gets better when you play with friends, but the comradery you can find in any teammate when trying to achieve a common goal makes every match an experience like no other. Too many hackers tho

I would not recommend this game to anyone for anything but the solo story mode.  

The multiplayer is 90% cheaters, as EA Games doesn't have an effective cheat-prevention module.  Channels on YouTube highlight cheaters who can show all enemies on their screen, alter the movement/speed of their own character to supernatural levels, shoot through walls and buildings, and even kick people off the servers to reduce the opposing team to half or quarter capacity, thus ensuring their win.  I've recorded some "spectator" mode footage myself, and noted that players flying planes were bots: they had 0 bombs on their planes, and yet still were able to drop 8 - 12 bombs per pass.  I've also recorded gameplay of the cheaters' health being replenished from 10% back to full 100% in 3 seconds, unlimited ammunition, and some type of script they run on their server connection that enhances the lethality of shots to the point that they don't even need to be firing close to you in order to kill you.  Additionally, on their mini map, the cheaters have MW3-style full UAV mode, seeing where you are at all times on the map. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RgAj0-OrXAo  

This is really unfortunate, that a wonderfully-made game has such a short shelf-life.  This game answers my prayers for a war game with great aesthetics & interplay; is not suffocated by activity and "paranormal" attributes given to soldiers, such as the COD/Modern Warfare dynasty -- except for one thing: the "teleportation" element of Snipers' radios allowing any players to enter at that point.  I'm so over the "supernatural" realm entering into otherwise "realistic" games.  Battlefield has a very clever & realistic attention to sound (utilizing echo and reverb), realistic object spacing & realistic timing, but the movement -- the distance a character can cover at running speed -- is a little stretched.  The story lines that are intriguing.  I played the solo missions in Norway as my first experience; the lush environment and character freewill was hypnotizing.  A shame this game has gone in the trash.

This game is still holding up really well.

It ain't no run and gun game, so if you're looking for that kind of BF game, check out BF1 and BF2042.

Battlefield 5 plays fairly more tactical and you're going to use covers a lot. Unlike games that take an aracade-ish approach, in BF5, a .22 caliber to the head from half a mile sends you back to the deployment screen.

Although, Team Deathmatch takes a different approach and encourages aggressive playstyles, as well as Firestorm (Battle Royale) which unfortunately is dead and almost impossible to find a lobby in. You're likely to wait 20 minutes to find a solo game and the lobby still wouldn't be full. That's a shame cause Firestorm is really fun. 

The campaign is probably one of the best I've ever played and it's immersion could mark my words. Instead of playing mission after mission as most campaigns force you to, in BF5, the missions are an open world battleground in which you decide in what order you should get your tasks done. The storyline itself also is one of the best out there.

Last but not least, there are no pay to win bundles. I was surprised to see that an EA game isn't based on microtransactions.

The game is fun and worth buying even in 2023.

Battlefield 5 is an exciting game full of dynamics and epic battles. The graphics in the game are incredibly realistic, the world is recreated with stunning detail, and every detail is worked out to perfection.

One of the most impressive features of Battlefield 5 is the scale of the battles. You can fight on huge maps, including destructible surrounding objects, which gives the game the feeling of a real war. Battles unfold in various theatres of war, such as Europe, Asia and Africa, allowing players to immerse themselves in a diverse history.

A huge selection of weapons and equipment also adds variety to the game. You can choose between different classes, each with unique skills and capabilities. Various types of weapons are available, from rifles and pistols to tanks and aeroplanes. The availability of different modes of transport allows players to choose the appropriate tactics and strategy in battle.

The multiplayer component in Battlefield 5 also leaves a pleasant impression. It offers various modes and maps where players can fight with other players around the world. The progression system and various achievements give the game durability and increase motivation to continue the game.

However, some players may find some issues in the gameplay balance. Some weapons and classes may seem too strong or weak in comparison with others, which may cause some dissatisfaction among experienced players. Also, some players note some technical problems and errors in the game, although the developers are actively working to fix these problems.

In general, Battlefield 5 is an exciting and serious game that allows you to plunge into the atmosphere of war and fight epic battles. Despite some problems, the game has great potential and is sure to please fans of the series and fans of shooters in general.

I bought the game despite the reviews saying the game is filled with cheaters because of the few people saying community servers are clean and moderated. It turns out, out of all the community servers there are only a few which have a suitable enough ping to play on, and even fewer are actually moderated. I would say half (feels like more than half though) of community servers that I've tried are allowing cheaters. As for the cheating, I've seen plenty of people speed hacking. I think thats the more common (and obvious to spot) cheat. I found 2 players in a match which were suspiciously consistent and fast at hitting shots. One of them was using a sniper and was headshotting people instantly. The other was using a machine gun and was also killing me before I had the chance to even spot him after peeking out of cover. Both of them had an irregularly high score compared to most other players. Both of them were also hitting me behind walls/through terrain every once in a while. 

I bought the game on sale for 12 bucks, and I would say its not worth any more than that in its current state. Absolutely do not recommend spending full price on this. Its a fun game but its been ruined by cheaters and by EA/Dice unwilling to moderate it in any meaningful way.

Definitely recommend the game in 2023 still. I am long time Battlefield series enjoyer (since BF3 and BF4 PS3 days). This game is one of the most cinematic games ever, from the world environment details to the movement, reloading, injury etc. animations. Overall I would say it makes an excellent job portraying World War 2 battle action in a video game. Definitely give this game a try if you are large scale multiplayer shooter enjoyer and if you want to lay your eyes on the most gorgeous gaming graphics out there.

Battlefield 5 is an exciting game full of dynamics and epic battles. The graphics in the game are incredibly realistic, the world is recreated with stunning detail, and every detail is worked out to perfection.

One of the most impressive features of Battlefield 5 is the scale of the battles. You can fight on huge maps, including destructible surrounding objects, which gives the game the feeling of a real war. Battles unfold in various theaters of war, such as Europe, Asia and Africa, allowing players to immerse themselves in a diverse history.

A huge selection of weapons and equipment also adds variety to the game. You can choose between different classes, each with unique skills and capabilities. Various types of weapons are available, from rifles and pistols to tanks and airplanes. The availability of different modes of transport allows players to choose the appropriate tactics and strategy in battle.

The multiplayer component in Battlefield 5 also leaves a pleasant impression. It offers various modes and maps where players can fight with other players around the world. The progression system and various achievements give the game durability and increase motivation to continue the game.

However, some players may find some issues in the gameplay balance. Some weapons and classes may seem too strong or weak in comparison with others, which may cause some dissatisfaction among experienced players. Also, some players note some technical problems and errors in the game, although the developers are actively working to fix these problems.

In general, Battlefield 5 is an exciting and serious game that allows you to plunge into the atmosphere of war and fight epic battles. Despite some problems, the game has great potential and is sure to please fans of the series and fans of shooters in general.

If you've been watch Band of Brothers or The Pacific, then give this a whirl. Do note though that community games are where its at - to minimize hackers ruining your game play. Nonetheless, if you're a casual gamer with a 9-5 job, I wouldn't recommend getting it at full price unless you have too much money to spare. The game play can get repetitive fast (spawn, die, repeat) and the single-player is limited to only the campaign, which is unfortunate.

I think it's a given that future entries of games and movies should be generally better than their previous installments. Battlefield V, in many aspects, is far-and-away an improvement over it's predecessor, Battlefield 1. Movement, gun-play, and the overall game-play loop sees greatly appreciated changes and updates, that give players more freedom and options in the Battlefield sandbox. Additions like crouch-running offers flexibility in a player's tactical toolkit, and the Fortifications system allow individual squads and players to better contribute to the entire team's success, and provides more ability and incentive to defend objectives. The Reinforcements system further promotes team-play and cohesiveness within squads, by giving squad leaders strong rewards for setting and completing orders, and allowing them to turn the tide of an engagement. There are an innumerable other changes I could mention; in essence, Battlefield V is utterly, an unequivocal technical and game-play improvement over Battlefield 1. For that reason I recommend BFV to people to have played and enjoyed Battlefield 1; though for all the improvements of BFV, in it's current state it is somewhat buggy, and has a serious issue with blatant cheaters in many servers.

This is a fun game about half of the time if you get a full lobby on a good map. Some maps you will lose 9/10 times if you're one the wrong side simply because the enemy team can field more armor than you can. Tanks in this game are busted where they are near impossible to take out as infantry unless you have multiple guys shooting them with bazookas because your sticky bombs are useless since tanks can sit in third person and will see you coming from 20 meters away. By far the biggest issue though is the number of cheaters. Out of every 10 games you will run into cheaters at least twice. The worst part is these guys are blatant and it takes days for them to get banned. They will get mass reported for aimbotting you 200 meters away in a tank turret or speed hacking straight to you and killing you 10 seconds after spawning and then will follow you into the next game for about 2 hours. Buy at your own risk.

The story campaign feels like rushed expansion pack DLC.  I'm shocked that such a well known developer would ever release something this devoid of effort.
-The maps are small and stories short.
-Characters get hung up on invisible objects and run in place.
-Your shots frequently don't register. 
-Any enemy that mounts a turret becomes impervious to gunfire from the front. Even when you shoot them in their fully exposed heads.
-With some of the machine guns you can hip fire a full 30 round clip at an enemy 6 feet in front of you and not hit them once.
Honestly, I've seen lone developers kitbash better and more polished games

Battlefield V is a visually stunning and action-packed addition to the iconic Battlefield series. DICE has once again managed to deliver an immersive World War II experience that takes gamers on a thrilling journey through some of the most iconic battles in history.

The graphics in Battlefield V are nothing short of spectacular. The attention to detail in the game's environments, weapons, and character models is awe-inspiring. Every battlefield feels alive and filled with an impressive level of destruction, adding to the realism of the game. The Frostbite engine truly shines in this iteration.

The gameplay in Battlefield V maintains the series' signature large-scale battles and destructible environments. Whether you're assaulting a fortified enemy position or defending it, the game offers a variety of maps and modes that cater to different playstyles. The addition of Grand Operations is a highlight, providing epic multi-day battles with unique objectives.

One of the major changes in Battlefield V is the removal of the traditional class system, replaced by the more flexible "Combat Roles." While this change might not sit well with everyone, it adds a layer of adaptability to the gameplay, allowing players to customize their loadout and role more freely.

The sound design in Battlefield V is extraordinary. The roar of tanks, the ping of bullets, and the screams of soldiers all contribute to an immersive experience. It's clear that DICE has spared no effort in making the auditory elements as authentic as possible.

However, it's worth noting that Battlefield V had its share of issues, particularly at launch, such as balance problems and missing content. But DICE actively listened to the community and provided numerous updates and patches to address these concerns. As a result, the game has evolved and improved significantly since its release.

The single-player War Stories are engaging, providing a fresh perspective on World War II through various short campaigns. They may not be as memorable as some other single-player titles, but they offer a nice change of pace from the multiplayer action.

In summary, Battlefield V is an outstanding addition to the Battlefield series, offering breathtaking visuals, intense gameplay, and a compelling take on World War II. It's a must-play for fans of the franchise and anyone looking for an immersive and action-packed multiplayer shooter. Despite its rocky start, DICE's ongoing support and improvements have made it a worthy contender in the genre.

With the addition of the Pacific Theater and other content updates, Battlefield V has only become more captivating over time. Whether you're a seasoned veteran or a newcomer to the series, this game is well worth your time and attention.

This game is so sad, the game itself is amazing and one of the best evolutionary paths BF could have taken, but the developers gave up for the nightmare known as 2042, as it stand the game feels complete other than a lack of any German-Soviet theater of war. People with access to the games source code have been non stop cheating in the game since 2020, to the point of which one person could join the server and within minutes the server will barren and empty, if there was even a minute amount of anti-cheat to save this game it would be one of the best battlefield games period. The campaign is great its way of story telling is similar to that of BF1 where you follow characters in their theaters of war, all of them have great stories and writing but the whole time the campaign is teaching you how to play. The multiplayer is great, metas are not rock solid and can be beat by other guns, it just requires a little getting use to the pros and cons of every weapon,  the gunplay feels smooth and fun, armored vehicles fit this perfect balance of being killable but requiring braincells and teamwork to do so, planes are a bit dumb, if they are equipped with rockets they can hit the AA guns outside the AA's range, but nothing a fleigerfaust cant fix. Customization in this game is something that started the entire controversy of this game, with the paraplegics and people with bionic prosthesis, but after their fixes its actually really good, and you dont even need to spend money to get better ones too, this game was a bit before the heavy micro-transaction era and so most of the big cosmetic upgrade packs can be earned in game with company coins. 

Overall this game is pretty great, but it feels neglected for no good reason.

It really is a shame they stopped making Battlefield games back in 2013.  BF1 and forward have more resembled a fast-paced CoD than Battlefield, since vehicles are rarely accessible because of the spawn-in system and on foot movement speeds would make Sonic look slow.  Gone are the days of Battlefield 1942, BF2, BF2SF, and BF2142, where vehicles just spawned out in the map for you to jump in whenever you want, and the general speed of the round actually made it possible to plan attacks and defenses with friends - or even find your friend for more than a few seconds, for that matter.  The round actually felt like a *battle*, not just a mindless brawl.  Even BF3 and BF4 had a small taste of this, though both were much faster than the original series of games.

Maybe I'm just getting old, but when I can play CoDMW multiplayer and feel it's more slow and tactical than a Battlefield game, Battlefield is dead.  Luckily I only paid $5 for this one.

IMPORTANT UPDATE: Since creating this review most european ROBOT Servers have been removed since it was found out that virtually everybody hosting a ROBOT Server cheated themselves. So yeah, welcome to BFV
--- End Update
Normal matchmaking doesn't work on public servers thanks to cheaters en mass, so the first recommendation you will get, if you google this problem, is to go to community servers => search for servers with [ROBOT] in their name.

However, most of those don't really use anti cheat protection, you will commonly find people will 100 kills to 4 deaths or something of the sort. 

The server where you have that protection are still a solid gaming experience, however, according to the data they show you can still expect at least 1% of players to be cheaters - Just are reminder, those 1% of people playing are found out cheaters on community servers with extra protection, so you can imagine the amount of unreported or not found cases. And way, way more on the official server without any protection at all.

Since community servers are run by private persons, you can be banned for no reason at all at any time from that server. And some of them have, weirdly enough, strong "Anti-China talk not allowed" rules. 

I'm still having fun, 2 of 3 games are a solid experience, no trouble finding games as of 10/23, but if a friend came to me and ask if he should buy BFV, it would be a no.

EA has completely abandoned this game. It is overrun with hackers. They don't even have to be a player in the game. Text chat is useless because it is non-stop spam by a bot. If there isn't a cheater in the game, just play for 30 minutes or less- one will soon join and disrupt the game so badly that players will leave the server in droves.
It would take EA literally just a few seconds to perma-ban these accounts, but they refuse. All my attempts to draw attention to issues fall on deaf ears.
Because it is so rampant and started almost immediately after the launch of 2042, my only conclusion is that EA is allowing or actively trying to destroy this game to drive people to buy the new game.

As such, I will never, ever, EVER purchase an EA game again. Because as soon as something new comes out, EA has demonstrated the problems with still very-good-games skyrocket to unplayable heights.

the overall gameplay and multiplayer are pretty fun. i like how sniping feels in this game. thats about all the good i have to say about this game at the moment. admited the game is basically dead at this point and has been for a while. im not a fan of the last few games that i litterally just had. finally got some games where someone wasnt blatantly cheating, and yet i spent a good 20min of that game spawning and either instantly dying because of spawn campers either in tanks or dive bombing in planes. to even just a random dude camped right next to a spawn point so they can shotgun you instantly. dont get me wrong i get it its a game. but ive been on both sides of that, and it isnt fun spending most of the 30 minute game doing nothing either because you keep dying or because you cant fucken find anyone. 

thats if you get a game without a cheater. if you do there is no question about it. ive had a few games where my bullets litteraly would hit someone they cock thier head back you get the blood animation and them continue to shoot at you. this is while im using a sniper. but didnt get a hit marker. either that or the lag gets to it and goes right through. but this is a base game issue that has to do more with how it handles lag. with 64 players in a lobby sometimes things happen and whatever no big deal. but when its like that the entire game it feels like youve been given a nerf gun in a gun fight against 8 people with real 240 bravos. when you get a cheater it makes that worse. everything from instant respawn. (they get ragdolled by a tank, then after thier body lands thier up again and still shooting. saw someone do this 6 times in a row) to people basically just having god mode/speed hacks, infinate ammo spamming snipers at 500rpm like an lmg its dumb. 

all that and there is an increasing likelyhood that you log on and thier is no games active. (nobody else in the world is playing) ive logged in to find this a few times lately. at one point the servers were dedicated based on region alone. now if your country shares a native language with another they lump those sometimes as much as 4 regions togeather and thats the coomon servers for that area. that and private games really are all ive seen active. you may get lucky durring the weekend and get to play a few actually decent games. but aside from that the game isnt worth it. its been long abandoned by ea, to include banning cheaters. i spent 7 dollars on this game and honestly it was fun while it lasted but it frustrates me how good this game could have still been let alone could be, if only ea stepped in and actually did thier part. i wouldnt spend 30-60 on this game in the current state its in. especially considering its not likely to change

okay, this is definitely the worst Battlefield ever. :'3
DICE, stop trying to copycat other FPS games.

about this game, it is simultaneously good and bad.

______________________

update: summarising... this game is just a Battlefield inspired FPS.
it is not an Battlefield game.

after playing BF4, BF1 and the latest BF2042, BFV always felt weird for me...
in suspicion, I compared their differences and realised that BFV is really different from all Battlefield series.

the most critical problems in this game:

- the perspective, the gun model.
I saw some complains about the visibility of this game, and, personally, I agree that this game's visibility is really bad. here is why:
・it is because they use a perspective called "1-point perspective", which is... everything that goes to the centre of the screen will become distant and smaller.
・the rendering of the character models, for some reason, becomes the same colour of brightness of ambient shadows. making literally everything "invisible", in full-camouflage because of the rendering.
・the gun perspective, in major Battlefield and other FPS games, the gun's muzzle (the tip), normally is "distant" by perspective. but, in BFV, it is more like a "side-view" of the gun, which makes the feeling that the gun is HUGE. 
・changing FOV will not help with the visibility.
・Nvidia game filters is an option to help you about the visibility issues. (helps just a bit.)

- the gunplay.
・bullet drop mechanics / physics are too exaggerated, all guns is this BFV is Nerf Guns. the bullets are just Nerf darts.
・the gun models are too big.
/ every gun in this game feels like the stationary machine gun / heavy machine gun from BF1. 
・the sighs are too big. 
/ you cannot change the magnifications like older Battlefields.
/ you have only 4 options of sighs in total. 

- leveling system.
・it is bad.
/ it takes too long to level up. 
/ some guns and vehicles with higher level, of course, will have their specialisations active, and that makes them really broken. it is unnecessary to make a leveling system that only makes the game unfair. 
/ because of this problem above, it is hard to level up everything in this game.

- some features.
/ AA guns hit reach is broken. it doesn't even make sense. they should have been like the AA guns of BF1.
/ AT guns are too weak.
/ high level vehicles are too unbalanced and unfair.
/ planes can reach the opponent's plane deploy base with no penalty. 

______________________

best points of the game:

- the physics detail.
examples are, when you walk through a flower field, they will fall toward, explosives in the water will make the liquid emerge,  flags wave "more-realistically".

- the character models.
they are just beautiful and well detailed. you can choose their visuals and customise their outfits.

- the "specialisation" system.
you can unlock an "equipment" (perk) for your character that gives you advantages in game rounds.
such as, increase of suppression, it will mess your opponent's aim.
well, in BFV, it is already unlocked from the start!

- the ground.
they just fixed the buggy ground, the characters and vehicles doesn't stuck in nowhere anymore. (sometimes, rarely, they does tho. but, it is rare.)

- crafting mechanics.
it is the greatest feature to be added in this game, you can create a cover when it is necessary, great for big maps with no cover. (but, DICE did not added this feature to some places that should be added...)

______________________

neutral points of the game:

- the leveling up system.
well, it is a interesting decision of DICE about forcing the players to use the weapons.
the thing is, if you want customise those weapons, you need to level up each weapon to the level 4.
・the good point is, you can try a several different weapons.
・the bad thing is, to unlock the weapon's specialisations, you need to level up each weapon to the level 4 + to unlock the weapon specialisations, you need to pay in-game coins to unlock.

______________________

not good points of the game:

- the weapons, the shooting, the reload system. (disclaimer, the animation itself is great!) 

・about the weapons, the shooting. 
well, it may because they made it to be more realistic, more "physics", so, the projectiles just falls more "realistically".
but, seeing the projectiles falling, it just feels like you are using with airsofts in WWII.
for me, it felt like every single weapon in this game became a sniper rifle. 
・about the reload.
the reload cancels for no reason sometimes. 

- the immersibility of the voice acting. 

・for some reason, they removed the announcer and changed to a high patent military personnel that speaks English regardless of the nationality of soldier which you are playing with. 
it just felt weird and less-immersive. 
・when you got hit, and need a revive, the voice is out of sync. honestly, it is less realistic than BF1, which you can feel their agony and fear in each voice in various situations.
BFV agonising voices are more... "soft"? 

- the enemy spotting / danger ping + ambient / model rendering, ambient lightning and colour palettes.  

・unlike the other Battlefields, you cannot spot and highlight enemies.
synced to this above, in meanings of colour, BFV is very, very bright. 
・the anti-aliasing is too strong at the point the soldiers become invisible. (regardless if they are moving or not.)
not even in Argonne Forest (BF1), soldiers were invisible like in BFV.

- some maps.

・some maps feels TOO BIG, or too small. 
a bit lifeless / "plastic" looking? 
some of them, just a big field with just colours and no cover.
some of them, just tight buildings. 

- vehicles

totally imbalanced when you are new to the game and you try to dogfight against an opponent with more play time. 
you cannot customise when all vehicles are all taken.
(they have way better specialisations.)

- the microtransaction system, the store. (and, probably this aspect is totally EA's fault.)

・well, this one in particular is the worst.
you can be a Japanese soldier while you are supposed to be The US Army's side, 
you can be an American soldier while you are supposed to be German Army's side, and also and obviously... 
you can use a German soldier while you are supposed to be The US Army's side... 
they should have locked specific skins to specific nationalities to keep the "realism", DICE wanted to reach.

Graphics on Battlefield V are a bit weird, even with everything on ultra I feel like there's something wrong, I can't exactly point it out but it does not feel good nor bad, just weird. Probably it's due to some maps being on day and bright as hell, especially the countryside ones, the cities are great however. Gameplay feels a lot more fluid than B1 and I liked that now you can revive with any class, so that's cool. 

The story was very good, and for the usual $5 sale I say it's very worth it, as it is common with multiplayer games the campaign is short, but tons of fun and an actual challenge on the higher difficulties. Now regarding multiplayer, you'll find about 2 hackers every two games but it didn't annoy me that much, and if you play on community games you'll never see one.

I didn't like the characters customization thing since most of the times I wasn't sure if I was shooting the enemy or not, for me it was something difficult to get used to. To conclude, solid game with an excellent campaign, definitely wait for sale.

[h1]Verdict:
B Tier,
7/10,
3.5 stars,
[/h1]

[b]Worth a Buy?[/b]
No, if you're solely interested in playing singleplayer or you value historical accuracy. Yes, if you prefer multiplayer because there are still a lot of players playing it, but be aware that you will run into cheaters and that is why I don't recommend it. Additionally, the price is excessive, thereby purchasing during a sale is recommended. 

[b]The Good:[/b]
- Missions can be replayed.
- War stories can be played at any order.
- Skippable cutscenes.
- An Axis focused war story.
- War stories are in their native languages.
- HUD can be customised.
- The audio is outstanding and realistic.
- The soundtrack is excellent.
- Good destruction and levolution.
- Graphics and visuals are great
- Tutorial sandbox map.
- Gunplay feels good.
- Good stable performance.
- Fun multiplayer.
- Improved movement such as leaning and crouch sprinting.

[b]The Bad:[/b]
- EA app launcher is required.
- You can't pause cutscenes
- Many unneeded stealth sections.
- The campaign's stealth mechanics don't actually function well.
- Historical revisionism.
- Censorship of historical symbols and the chat filter.
- The campaign AI is very buggy and awful.
- Campaign can be buggy.
- The campaign has very bad writing and gameplay design.
- Cosmetic microtransactions.
- High Price tag.
- 90GB install size.
- Anti-Cheat is useless.
- Many Cheaters.
- Some gamemodes are inactive.
- Community servers have less features.
- Loading times can sometimes feel a bit too long.
- Very CPU intensive.

[b]The Neutral & Informational:[/b]
- Multiplayer is prioritised above single-player.
- A 100% achievement completion rate requires completion of multiplayer achievements.
- Some of the changes to the standard battlefield gameplay could be considered good or bad.
- Historical accuracy is god awful.
- Arcade shooter with a little bit of realism.
- Maps can be big or small.
- Accessibility options for colourblind users.
- Multiple protagonists.
- Multiple campaigns.
- 5–7 hour campaign.
- There's hardly much blood or gore.
- Player customisation.
- All weapon and equipment are unlocked.
- CO-OP missions.
- Doesn't really feel like a WW2 game.

[b]Performance:
Windows 11, 165hz 1080p Monitor, GPU: 8GB RTX 3060Ti, CPU: Intel i7-12700F, 16GB DDR4 3200MHz RAM, SSD [/b]
- Didn't experience any crashes or freezing.
- Stable performance at the highest settings.
- Very CPU intensive.

[b]Bugs & Glitches:[/b]
- Softlocked twice when using binoculars, unable to change weapons or complete any campaign objectives. During the Norway War Story, I had to restart to a checkpoint twice because the game softlocked and I couldn't continue the story. One of these was brought on the mother getting stuck on a desk. https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3030257441

[b]Difficulty:[/b]
- 4/5 rating. This was a significant step up in difficulty from earlier games when played in hardcore mode. At times, especially during the unplayable stealth sections which conclude in a gun and spray, it can feel unfair. You'll spend a lot of time prone after getting shot, waiting for your health to replenish. I also tried the hard setting, and it felt about the same as previous game's hard setting. Ammo is once again plentiful, and health recovery is still quick.

[b]Additional Information:[/b]
[b]- Historical Accuracy:[/b] It's horrible, really bad. In war stories, it also includes some offensive historical revisionism. No consideration is given to the distribution of weapons because occasionally you may find late-war weapons in an early-war situation. Censorship of historical emblems and flags undermines immersion and logic. Includes non-historical female soldiers in multiplayer. 

[b]- Campaign Stealth:[/b] Same stealth in Battlefield 1, basically. They didn't even make it better. In a battlefield game, stealth portions are completely unnecessary, but level designers adore them. The AI detection is flawed because I frequently saw instances of them finding me, such as on hardcore when they were able to see me through walls and such. Additionally, you can engage in a shootout with AI, and enemies who are merely nearby won't even react.

[b]- The Campaign:[/b] It was a horrendously awful experience that felt unnecessary. contains a lot of stealth sections as well. Only "The Last Tiger" is the story. I advise you to play considering it was  good. I'll now give a brief overview of my campaign experience.

[b]War Story 1: 3/10, D tier.[/b] A rather boring story: 1 man army situations; The dialogue is poor and artificial; The other two SBS members vanish and are not present; Using homemade explosives; A random plane appears and knows where you are; When you are unarmed, a German driving a jeep approaches you and points an mp40 at you; When the screen goes black, the German is in the trunk; Because an evacuation point was never planned for, you must rely on a German radio to request one. German in the trunk remains uninjured despite the vehicle being shot through multiple times; Despite not knowing where you are, a rescue team manages to save you at the ideal time.

[b]War Story 2: 2/10, E++ tier.[/b] Revisionist history the mission, such an offensive retelling of the actual operation; Had two softlocks as well; Skiing was enjoyable; 1 women army moments; The majority of the mission is stealth, and you can shoot searchlights but not regular lights; An 18-year-old girl can outmatch males of military age; Instead of shooting you, a German suddenly spawns and charges towards you; Mother teleports over to the bridge; You avoided harm despite being flung from a bridge and falling down a mountain; You plunge down a cliff into a lake in subfreezing weather; You live, and there is no damage to the documents; In a lake, a submarine; Stupid bunker ambush; In a shootout near the submarine, two Germans sneak up on you. Mother flees with a grenade, and the guy shoots her in the stomach rather than killing her. He then doesn't finish her off, and she then blows up the submarine.

[b]War Story 3: 4/10, D++ tier.[/b] A missed opportunity of a good story due to historical revisionism and inaccurate portrayals of the Tirailleur; Although there are big battles in the story stealth is still present; In one scene, you and your companions are defeated and killed, and you are knocked out. When you finally awaken, everything is fine.

[b]War Story 4: 7/10, B tier.[/b] The best story, though, suffers from being too short. Wish the campaign was run this way the entire time. The writing was decent but again suffers from being too short. Unfortunately, this mission contains a lot of censored imagery, notably the German flag. With little to no stealth, the mission is primarily carried out in a Tiger tank. Although it seems implausible that a single tank can easily wipe out a whole army. Even so, it was enjoyable. Also, the level destruction was excellent because to your use of the tank's weapon. The only good war story.

Edit 9/9/2023: I came back to this game and it's in the worst state so far. I would not recommend buying Battlefield 5 in 2023. The game crashes frequently. Cheaters are absolutely rampant, and the servers are mostly dead. You might find one or two games with low enough ping, and then they'll be filled with cheaters or squads of veteran players rolling through win after win. Save your money, Battlefield V is over. 

This game could be great, but cheaters ruin it consistently. There's apparently no anti-cheat system whatsoever because you'll have multiple games in a row where the same guy goes 150-0, headshotting everyone with an aimbot. If EA would actually try to prevent cheating and fix some of the annoying issues that still exist (getting stuck in place as if there's a wall in front of you), this game would be as good as Battlefield 1 was in its heyday. 

Another issue you'll run into frequently is lack of balancing. In Battlefield 1, teams would autobalance so you'd have a chance of winning. In Battlefield V, you'll lose multiple games in a row if the enemy team is particularly good. Now that there's few active servers,  this becomes very irritating.

Edit: It seems to be getting worse. Cheaters will openly brag about it in the in-game chat, and about how easy it is to just make a new account for free when they get banned. Not sure why DICE abandoned this game because its better than 2042.

Edit a few weeks later: Cheating is getting even worse and more blatant. I don't know why I keep playing, honestly, except that when you finally get a game without cheaters, it's SO good. Tied with BF1 in my opinion. Its insane that DICE abandoned it so quickly.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

New York Cheesecake
Ingredients
For the crust
85g butter, plus extra for tin
140g digestive biscuits, made into fine crumbs (add 2 extra biscuits if you like a thicker base)
1 tbsp sugar, granulated or golden caster
For the cheesecake filling
900g Philadelphia cheese, or other full-fat soft cheese
250g golden caster sugar
3 tbsp plain flour
1 ½ tsp vanilla extract
finely grated zest of 1 lemon (about 2 tsp)
1 ½ tsp lemon juice
3 large eggs, plus 1 yolk
284ml carton soured cream
For the soured cream topping
142ml carton soured cream
1 tbsp golden caster sugar
2 tsp lemon juice
Method

STEP 1
Position an oven shelf in the middle of the oven. Heat the oven to 180C/ 160C fan/ gas 4.

STEP 2
Line the base of a 23cm springform cake tin by putting a square piece of parchment paper or foil on top of the tin base and then clipping the side on so the paper or foil is trapped and any excess sticks out of the bottom.

STEP 3
For the crust, melt 85g butter in a medium pan. Stir in 140g digestive biscuit crumbs and 1 tbsp golden caster or granulated sugar so the mixture is evenly moistened.

STEP 4
Press the mixture into the bottom of the pan and bake for 10 minutes. Cool on a wire rack while preparing the filling.

STEP 5
For the filling, increase the oven temperature to fan 220C/ 200C fan/ gas 7. In a table top mixer fitted with the paddle attachment, beat 900g full-fat soft cheese at medium-low speed until creamy, about 2 minutes.

STEP 6
With the mixer on low, gradually add 250g golden caster sugar, then 3 tbsp plain flour and a pinch of salt, scraping down the sides of the bowl and the paddle twice.

STEP 7
Swap the paddle attachment for the whisk. Continue by adding 1½ tsp vanilla extract, 2 tsp lemon zest and 1½ tsp lemon juice. Whisk in 3 large eggs and 1 yolk, one at a time, scraping the bowl and whisk at least twice.

STEP 8
Stir a 284ml carton of soured cream until smooth, then measure 200ml (just over ¾ of the carton). Continue on low speed as you add the measured soured cream (reserve the rest). Whisk to blend, but don't over-beat. The batter should be smooth, light and somewhat airy.

STEP 9
Brush the sides of the springform tin with melted butter and put on a baking sheet. Pour in the filling - if there are any lumps, sink them using a knife - the top should be as smooth as possible. Bake for 10 minutes.

STEP 10
Reduce oven temperature to 110C/ 90C fan/ gas ¼ and bake for 45 minutes more. If you gently shake the tin, the filling should have a slight wobble.

STEP 11
Turn off the oven and open the oven door for a cheesecake that's creamy in the centre, or leave it closed if you prefer a drier texture. Let cool in the oven for 2 hours. The cheesecake may get a slight crack on top as it cools.

STEP 12
Combine the reserved soured cream with a 142ml carton soured cream, 1 tbsp golden caster sugar and 2 tsp lemon juice for the topping. Spread over the cheesecake right to the edges. Cover loosely with foil and refrigerate for at least 8 hours or overnight.

STEP 13
Run a round-bladed knife around the sides of the tin to loosen any stuck edges. Unlock the side, slide the cheesecake off the bottom of the tin onto a plate, then slide the parchment paper out from underneath.

RECIPE TIPS
MIXING THE INGREDIENTS
The way you blend the ingredients is crucial: under-beating can lead to a lumpy mixture, over-beating can whip in too much air. This can result in uneven cooking, bubbles, and cracking.

KEEP EVERYTHING AT ROOM TEMPERATURE
Keep everything at room temperature.

To avoid lumps and ensure even mixing without over-beating, it is essential to have the soft cheese at room temperature before starting. Ideally, let it come to room temperature in its pack for 2 hours. If you're short of time, cut the soft cheese into chunks and leave to soften for 1 hour. It also helps to have a tabletop mixer with a powerful motor. But if you don't have one, a hand-held mixer works fine.

The only counter is robot servers, but those are all stationed in Asia and have little "bells and whistles" that just make the game less enjoyable. I cannot give this game a positive review until the issue is resolved, which considering the way DICE/EA works, abandoning projects when a successor comes around, will likely be never.

Battlefield V was on sale for like 10 bucks so I bought it without hesitation.
I've been absent from the battlefield series since 2011 so here's a fresh look at Battlefield V:

[b] Campaign: [/b]
 While the campaign offers fresh and otherwise unknown perspectives of WWII, the singleplayer experience lacks depth. It's basically 5 "episodes" with a different protagonist in each one taking place in various fronts of WWII. It feels more like a tutorial rather than an actual story mode and if I'm not mistaken, BF 1 also had the same format. It can be fun for a while but the cinematic cutscenes and the stealth playstyle the campaign promotes most of the time ruins the fun imo and makes it feel like a knock-off Far Cry. FAR different approach in comparison with older story driven BF titles!

[b] Multiplayer: [/b]

The multiplayer is actually very fun, which makes me believe that BF5 development was multiplayer-centered. Fun weapons,balanced progression, great character and weapon customization, classic BF mechanics. The only issue someone will definitely encounter are the hackers, 4 out of 5 games have hackers on both teams, using speedhacks, aimbot and ruining the experience [u] but the solution is rather simple, [/u] don't play on DICE servers, play on community games and just like that *poof* hackers are gone.
The Ultimate Hacker Experience

I picked this game up when it was on sale on steam for quite a considerable bargain.

Graphics - 7/10
Gun Play - 8/10
Atmosphere - 7/10
Optimization - 9.5/10

This game is good if you're looking for a casual sandbox FPS that doesn't require you to sweat to have fun. The immersion is on point, the gun play is polished, the graphics are good, exactly the attributes you would want in an immersive FPS that you can actually enjoy. It doesn't quite have the atmosphere that Battlefield 1 does, as it's more, "bright" themed; lacking a gritty, war based atmosphere that makes battlefield, well, battlefield. Despite this unfortunate aspect, it still beats Battlefield 2042 in immersion and overall experience, which isn't really saying much, but at least its something. Movement feels a little clunky, especially when sliding and jumping, this provides a slower pace than most modern shooters. Due to Battlefields way of forcing clients to use anti-aliasing - which is an issue in numerous titles of the franchise - the graphics are a little more blurry on edges than i would prefer: this makes it hard to spot enemies in the distance. This game is very well optimized, especially if you compare it to Battlefield 2042. If you have an RTX GPU and would like to take advantage of DLSS, Battlefield V has the option, but they force you to turn on ray-tracing to use it, which is ludicrously stupid. Battlefield V has done a pretty decent job at fixing their bugs and glitches for the most part. I would say that the most annoying bug/glitch in Battlefield games are the rag doll physics after your character dies, feeling very unrealistic and sometimes glitching through the map, however Battlefield V is not the only entry in the franchise to fall victim to this specific issue.

My biggest con with this game is that the player base is dying, and it is sometimes hard to find a populated server in which to play on, as most of the player base are finally transitioning to battlefield 2042 after updates to the game. Because of this issue, I wouldn't recommend purchasing the game at full price at all, instead, waiting for a considerable sale is the best, "bang for your buck".

Despite having spent hundreds of hours playing this game, i still find it lacking in certain aspects, at least from my perspective. In a 20 vs 20 match, there are typically 3 or 4 players waiting  for an airplane or tank. With no means to communicate effectively with teammates, this lack of coordination has diminished the strategic elements of the game. The outcome, whether victory or defeat, seems to rely on just 1 or 2 skilled players. For instance, newcomers might achieve 10 kills but suffer 30 or 40 deaths. On the other hand, experts can achieve 100 or 200 kills without dying even once.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Battlefield V - A Gritty and Immersive World War II Experience

Rating: ★★★★☆

Battlefield V, released in 2018, brings players back to the tumultuous era of World War II, offering a visceral and immersive depiction of the conflict on both the grand scale and the personal level. With its detailed environments, strategic gameplay, and commitment to historical accuracy, the game delivers a captivating war experience that honors its roots while introducing new elements to the franchise.

The game's graphical prowess is immediately evident, with stunningly detailed maps that capture the devastation and chaos of the war. From the snow-covered landscapes of Norway to the urban battlegrounds of Rotterdam, each location feels authentically designed and meticulously crafted, immersing players in the gritty atmosphere of the conflict.

The single-player War Stories provide a series of poignant and diverse narratives that shed light on lesser-known aspects of World War II. These stories focus on individual soldiers and civilians, showcasing the personal sacrifices and challenges they faced during the war. While the narratives are engaging, some players may find them relatively short and yearn for more in-depth storytelling.

Multiplayer remains the heart of Battlefield V, offering large-scale battles and strategic gameplay that the series is known for. The "Attrition" system, where players have limited ammo and health, encourages teamwork and careful resource management. This shift adds depth to the gameplay, fostering a greater reliance on squad cooperation and strategic decision-making.

The "Fortifications" mechanic is a noteworthy addition, allowing players to construct defensive structures and fortify positions. This mechanic adds a layer of strategy and creativity to the gameplay, as players can adapt their surroundings to suit their playstyle and team objectives.

The class-based system returns with tweaks, offering distinct roles that contribute to the team's success. The addition of the "Grand Operations" mode, spanning multiple days and matches, provides an epic and evolving battle experience that showcases the ebb and flow of a war campaign.

Battlefield V's live service model ensures a consistent stream of content updates, introducing new maps, weapons, vehicles, and modes over time. This approach keeps the experience fresh and engaging, encouraging players to return for new challenges and experiences.

The game's commitment to historical accuracy is commendable, aiming to depict the weaponry, vehicles, and uniforms of the era authentically. However, some players may still find occasional historical inaccuracies or creative liberties taken for gameplay balance.

On the downside, the game faced criticism at launch for its initial lack of content and technical issues. While these concerns have been addressed through post-launch updates, they did impact the game's reputation during its early days.

In conclusion, Battlefield V offers an immersive and authentic World War II experience that successfully captures the intensity and scale of the conflict. With its stunning visuals, strategic gameplay, and commitment to historical accuracy, the game stands as a strong entry in the Battlefield series that will appeal to fans of both the franchise and historical shooters.

If you're a fan of realistic and tactical multiplayer shooters or have an interest in the historical events of World War II, Battlefield V is worth exploring as it provides a gripping and visceral depiction of the era's chaos and heroism.

So it is finally time to give my 2 cents about this game. I played this game on 2 platforms: Xbox and PC. Battlefield 5 started already good: The feministic move to add females on the front line was unacceptable. But that's not even what bothers me anymore, I unfortunately learned to live with it. No, what really bothers me are the cheaters in this game, using cheat engines, to enhance their chance on survival, and capabilities. Each match you enter, there will be someone in the chat say there is a cheater, and yep, a couple of seconds, after jumping in the field, you indeed get this confirmed. This is awful, and it makes me mad. 

There is absolutely nothing what we can do about it either, since the report system is not connected to an active staff that can deal with these reports, or because the anti-cheat is simply turned off. Because of these cheaters, the game became unplayable. You know when there is a cheater! With out a cheater, you will die, sure, but you will have kills. But as soon as there is a cheater, your "skill" is gone, and you will die, each time you spawn in, with out being able to kill someone. because you're pinned down always. 

I can imagine the game with out cheaters, and it is a fantastic game, minus the feminist flavor in it. IF I could sue Dice, or even those that creates these cheat engine I would've. There should be also a law that prevents cheating: Those that cheat must pay a high financial sum of money out of their own pocket, and even a year of prison. 

Many people on the internet however are rejecting that idea, and even dare to ask which punishment would be right, blablabla. These are probably the cheaters talking! I hate the game cheater, not the game. And I blame Dice, even though they don't see it that way. I feel powerless, and that fuels my anger. It is so unfair, and it is very rampant and obnoxious. I demand the developers to turn on anti cheat, I DEMAND it. I am a loyal BF-player, and I and all my mates playing this with out cheats, deserve such change!! It's the only thing we want, 

I personally don't care anymore that the females are there, you can overlook it. But cheaters are a big no no, and you MUST change that. YOU MUST! We haven't destroyed the game, you did, by allowing cheaters to thrive. With out that BS I would totally give you 3 points! But you are 0.5 points now. 

This game feels like a psychological attack on the gamer it self. The people that make these games are our enemies. They enforce things with out our consent, add and delete things we never asked for, and pushes an agenda we don't care for, and allow the biggest moral crime you can do to a player in game, using no cheats. the cheater, dominates the map, and bring them players in derision: allowing cheaters, was the foulest  thing you've done, after insulting our intelligence with this feminist move to add females at the front line. These females are an Stolen Valor issue, these females never ever seen combat on these battlefields, in these uniforms! 
Like I said: I would sue you if I could. But I am poor, so I can't. By God I wish I could. Shady mfers!

[h1] A nice WW2 FPS but not the best of the franchise[/h1]

[b] Overall [/b] : 7/10

BFV is all of what you expect from a battlefield game. 4 classes. Huge maps. Combined arms (air, land) and superb graphics. Yet, I still feel that this game is a stepdown from BF1, in pretty much all aspects. The Gunplay feels cluncky, the graphics show more of low res textures and the map designs are questionable. A nice addition if you find it on sales.

[b] Gameplay [/b] : 7/10

Very classic, nothing fancy here. The nice addition is the fact that as a Squad commander, you earn some requisition points that you can turn into perks, like artillery strike.
My biggest grip is with the gunplay, that somewhat feels cluncky. And the weapon balancing is just horrible in this game.

[b] Graphics [/b]: 7/10

Overall, some very nice scenery, especially in HDR. However, texture wise, the game seems to use some low res texture, and there is quite a bit of clipping as well.

[b] Story [/b] : 5/10

For the campaign, the game reiterate its concept introduced in BF1, with different war stories. They are short but nicely done. But really not memorable.

[b] Achievements [/b] : 7/10

For the hunters out there, this game is rather pleasant to 100%. Most of the trophies actually require you to play well the game. 1 (or 2) will be particularly challenging (the death from above one), but it just requires you to master the air game (and a bit of luck).

[h1]It's just not fun anymore.[/h1]

You've probably heard it before that that this game has a massive cheater problem, but outside of that, Battlefield V has fallen victim to the usual fate that most games of more than four years old face. The only people that are left playing are one of three types of people:

1: Sweats who play BF games for K/D instead of team play and don't play the objective
2: Tank mains who sit in one spot (usually in their spawn) the entire game and get close, if not, over 100 kills and no deaths
3: Hackers who use aimbot, ESP, literal unreleased weapons found in the game files and every other cheat known to man

It's worth mentioning that, contrary to popular belief, Battlefield V [i]does[/i] have an anti-cheat, but it is ridiculously slow. Someone can go weeks, sometimes months hacking and not get noticed by the AC. Even then, they'll just buy another $6 copy of the game and use it on another account. Funnily enough, Battlefield 2042 uses Easy Anti Cheat and I'm yet to encounter a single hacker in that game.

I will also say that, much like its predecessor, Battlefield V has always had a bit of a "meta" problem. In Battlefield 4 and 2042, you can use pretty much any gun and still be able to stand your own against the competition. But in Battlefield V? If you're not using the STG44 as an assault, Type 2A as a medic, KE7 as support, or ZH-29 as a scout, you're not going to stand much of a chance. The HMGs (MG-42, Browning 1919, etc.) are a joke in this game because they're the only guns that overheat, have long reload times due to being belt-fed, and the worst part: Can only be hip-fired when not prone/mounted with a bipod. A pretty funny contrast to Battlefield 1 where you could full sprint and ADS with a Browning M1917— which weighs over 100 pounds. I feel like this alone is probably the biggest problem that Battlefield V has at its core that just never got "fixed" or ironed out.

I feel like the player/vehicle balancing is pretty well-done, too. It's just that the way people play tanks in this game (as previously mentioned) makes them often unbearable. The tanks/planes themselves aren't unbalanced in the slightest (unlike other Battlefields) and it's very fun to play from both sides.

A lot of the maps are good, but some of them are abysmally horrible. Panzerstorm is a vehicle main's paradise (as you can probably tell from the name). It's a flat, open field with hardly any cover between objectives. It's like a taste of what the 2042 maps would be like in the near future. Two of the Pacific maps are some of the worst maps I've seen in the whole franchise. I'm of the belief that, when it comes to map design, Battlefield (and most first-person shooters, for that matter) is at its best when they're in an urban setting— because let me tell you. The urban maps in this game are oh-so good. Rotterdam, Provence, Operation Underground, Arras, Devastation, and Marita are all incredibly designed, balanced, fun to play on maps.

The gunplay and movement is, in my opinion, the best that the franchise has seen yet. It's jarring playing 2042 and then playing this because this game feels so much much more fluid compared to the latest installment. Crouch running, very satisfying vaulting/mantling, breaking your fall, sliding, proning on your back, everything feels great.

But the game just really isn't what it used to be. I haven't lost my touch, I just want to be able to do different things in the game like try a different gun or play slightly different from how I always play— but if you're not playing the exact same way that everyone else is (sweating your ass off and using meta guns/gadgets), you're up the creek.

The cheater problem is just the massive shit on the cake.
