Just wanted to clear something up. This game is amazing but yes, cheaters do ruin it and they can be a deal breaker, until now.

If you find yourself disliking this game due to the cheating pandemic there is an incredibly much more simple solution. Go to "Community Servers".

Official servers that are marked with [DICE] are likely going to be riddled with cheaters. These servers have outdated anti-cheat, and this is how cheaters are able to thrive in these matches.

Go to community servers, and join a high pop one. It will most likely have anti-cheat (because it has high pop) but if you want to be extra sure, servers tagged with [BFV ROBOT] in their title means they have the BFV ROBOT custom anticheat (which is very effective, ive spent 60+ hours on their servers and not encountered a single cheater)

If cheaters are the deal breaker for you here, community servers are the way.

!! And yes, progression is allowed on community servers so don't worry about that, though some server hosts may have it disabled.

UPDATE: 7/18 - More and more hackers everyday.  You won't find a lobby that doesn't have one.  Often, they will join a lobby, redeploy everyone for a few minutes to kill the pop, then hop to another server and do the same.  You'll see the same hackers daily, they seem to play about 10 hours a day, 5 days a week.  Reporting them does absolutely nothing.


You will find cheaters in nearly every game you play, typically more than one.  Still playable at times, but it really takes away from the fun of the game.  You'll see the same people cheating day after day after day (they hop around games mid way to rack up 50+ kills then leave).  I honestly would suggest another game that actually bans cheaters & has anti-cheat.  You can report the same people over and over again for blatant hacking (spin bot, one shot kill across map, ESP, etc.) and nothing ever happens. - P.S. want to spot a cheat?  Pull up their profile, if they don't have any other EA games and have a 25+ KD - Good chance they're cheating.

This game definitely belongs to the new generation of the Battlefield game series. Players who enjoy a fast-paced, endless shooting experience will appreciate it.

However, the large and open maps make it challenging to play with vehicles as they can be easily targeted and destroyed. 

If you prefer playing as a casual infantry soldier, you'll find it difficult to eliminate enemies with 250+ HP, especially with inferior guns. 

Spotting enemies can also be problematic due to complex terrain and fortifications. Transmitting information to teammates can be challenging as well, particularly without a weapon with a good scope.

I've heard numerous allegations about cheaters in Battlefield V, and it's quite "strange" to face opponents with scoreboards like 176/1 or 115/3 and consider them completely legitimate.

The campaign was somewhat okay, but it lacks the quality that previous BF games' campaigns had.

Considering the high price and questionable gameplay, I wouldn't recommend buying this game.

-Last year a big diarrhea called call of duty vanguard released and it single handedly make call of duty ww2 and battlefield v look like a masterpiece. Contrary to popular belief, this game dont have lesbian nazi unlike cod vanguard. 
 -Dont expect historical accuracy, the campaign is political pandering. But who tf play battlefield for campaign?
 -It had a pacific theater, something battlefield haven't make in 13 years. It is a mediocre game but you definitely gonna have fun charging (((amerika))) tank with lunge mine. 
 -It dont have the immersion and wow aspect of bf1 but the gunplay is 10x better, weapons actually had a recoil pattern, you can slide, crouch sprint....etc
 -If you want to avoid cheater then play on community server(usually named bfv robot), it's not rocket science
 -Get it on sales, for 5 bucks definitely more than worth it. Also the version on steam is the definitive edition so u dont need to grind for 1000 hours like bf4 lol.
 -Dice honestly fix your franchise, fcking bfv and bf1 had more player than bf 2042. As of July 2023, BF5 is the most played battlefield game on steam.

Skip the single-player and the store, go straight to Strategic Conquest, and it's 2002 all over again, but with every improvement Battlefield has picked up since then: the simple and useful squad system, spotting, lots of ways to support teammates, destructible (and somewhat fortifiable) environments, random weather, spectacular visuals and cacophonous audio. All the modern ancillary cruft of XP and weapon upgrades and customization really isn't that taxing either to be fair, and just comes as you play. Sometimes I just want to play 1942; sometimes I wish 1943 had made it to PC. Battlefield V satisfies both of those wants, easily and completely. Maybe one day I'll explore the rest of the game outside Strategic Conquest.

If you are looking for a review on this game you have come to the wrong place but, I can tell you how to make delicious Butter Chicken.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients for 4 servings,
2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast (910 g), cubed
salt, to taste
pepper, to taste
2 teaspoons chili powder, divided
½ teaspoon turmeric
6 tablespoons butter, divided
1 ½ cups yellow onion (225 g), diced
3 teaspoons garam masala
1 teaspoon cumin
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 tablespoon ginger, grated
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 cinnamon, 3 inch (8 cm) stick
14 oz tomato sauce (395 g)
1 cup water (240 mL)
1 cup heavy cream (240 mL)
rice, for serving
fresh cilantro, chopped for garnish.

Preparation
In a large bowl, season the chicken breast with salt, pepper, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and the teaspoon of turmeric. Let
sit for 15 minutes to marinate.
Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Brown the chicken, then remove from the pot.
Melt another 2 tablespoons of butter in the pot, then add the onion, garam masala, remaining teaspoon of chili powder,
the cumin, ginger, garlic, cayenne, cinnamon, salt and pepper. Cook until fragrant.
Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer.
Add the water and cream and return to a simmer.
Return the chicken to the pot, cover, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes.
Stir in the last 2 tablespoons of butter and season with more salt and pepper to taste.
Serve the chicken over rice and garnish with cilantro.
Enjoy!

Remember serve it when hot !!!

BFV is what Assassin's Creed Unity is, smooth, fancy, & refined. The ability to crouch run, 360 degree prone rotation, & sliding. Gunplay has the umph feeling. Graphically, its the best in the series so far. Sadly, it looks like we won't be getting a Battlefield like this anytime soon since 2042 removed most of these features.

[b] Campaign [/b] - The missions suffer from Battlefield 1's designs where it's structured half war zone then sudden stealth section. The length per story is very short, around 30 minutes to an hour short. With that in mind, I recommend the following War Stories: 

+ Tirailleur - Black French soldier & his brothers recapturing parts of France.
+ The Last Tiger - Wermacht perspective on the war.

[b] Multiplayer [/b] - If you want to experience this 5 year old product, be warned there are cheaters in official/community servers. It's possible to play without them but it's quite a hassle finding a cheater free server. The next step is to find a server not located in Germany for good ping unless you're a lucky European. Final note, meme guns & the maps feel inferior to BF1.

Creamy courgette lasagne

if you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding Creamy courgette lasagne recipe you've come to the right place,

Ingredients

9 dried lasagne sheets
1 tbsp sunflower oil
1 onion, finely chopped
700g courgette (about 6), coarsely grated
2 garlic cloves, crushed
250g tub ricotta
50g cheddar
350g jar tomato sauce for pasta

Directions

STEP 1
Heat oven to 220C/fan 200C/gas 7. Put a pan of water on to boil, then cook the lasagne sheets for about 5 mins until softened, but not cooked through. Rinse in cold water, then drizzle with a little oil to stop them sticking together.

STEP 2
Meanwhile, heat the oil in a large frying pan, then fry the onion. After 3 mins, add the courgettes and garlic and continue to fry until the courgette has softened and turned bright green. Stir in 2/3 of both the ricotta and the cheddar, then season to taste. Heat the tomato sauce in the microwave for 2 mins on High until hot.

STEP 3
In a large baking dish, layer up the lasagne, starting with half the courgette mix, then pasta, then tomato sauce. Repeat, top with blobs of the remaining ricotta, then scatter with the rest of the cheddar. Bake on the top shelf for about 10 mins until the pasta is tender and the cheese is golden.

Its mid

I grew up on Battlefield 1. Not only was I excited to return to the game with B5, I'm in general a patient and forgiving player.

The developers have chosen to force players to be exposed to blood and traumatic cries for help during death scenes. I wholeheartedly agree that war is hell, and everyone in society should be reminded of that. But is it healing or enlightening to actually spend your time for hours on end, virtually on the ground, virtually bleeding out, listening to a voice actor authentically voicing their humanity as they die, and for a player to experience that repeatedly?

I'm glad that experience exists in this game. The better choice, however, could have been to optionally turn off traumatic content after a certain threshold/level is achieved in the game. At a certain point, you as the player get those lessons.

Imagine the players of this game who get depressed, anxious, and nihilistic from playing it. The totality of the music, pained voices, and repeatedly passing into oblivion... I read the usernames of some people in the game, and without knowing them, I felt pain for them. Just pain and cringe in their usernames.

What if after experiencing war is hell, you as the user unlocked interviews with veterans discussing trauma, death, and PTSD? What if you could turn off trauma/blood/gore/graphic content after watching those interviews? Wouldn't that kind of experience do just as much, if not more to honor and respect the human beings we as players are intended to honor, respect, and understand?

[h1] Review[/h1] 
Battlefield games can be a hit or miss, you got half of their games being utter crap and the other pretty solid multiplayer shooter. I usually don’t like this type of game but im a sucker for world war 1 and 2 stuff. Initially a lot of people lost interest due to a variety of political and gameplay aspects of this game. I got it for free some time on origin and was actually surprised that its actually not a bad game, or at least for battlefield standards. But there are definitely some issues and a reason why you shouldn’t buy this game.

[u]Gameplay[/u]
The gameplay of the campaign is now focusing much more on open areas you can sneak through, scavenge weapons and ,mark enemies while doing objectives. This is aside for challenges completely optional and the stories that go along with this are quite enjoyble, having their own focus on a variety of gameplay aspects, one character as an example has skis and drives with snowmobiles around, or another one is a completely tank mission where you sometimes have to proceed on foot. Neat stuff, although still not a reason to get the game on full price solely.

The multiplayer now got rid off a couple of things that I disliked about 1, mainly the amount of inventory clutter you have with a lot of weapons that are either just skins or having attachments on them. Here you have way much less weapons, but can customize them a lot. Although its still weird that you can use a mp40 as a Japanese soldier, the game is just taking the world war 2 setting, or its assets, and mashes them together in the multiplayer. Im fine with this to a certain extent, its still silly to see Japanese soldiers helping attacking the Netherlands.

The combat is slightly improved over battlefield 1, you have less weapons due to reason I mentioned earlier and can tune them around with some scopes and for some reason literal red dot sights. Weapons can level and unlock challenges, although you can only activate 3 at a time, while you quickly get a variety of challenges unlocked. This is unnecessary, there is a lot of grind nonetheless here if you into unlocking stuff like that, as luckily the edition sold now unlocks all weapons from the get go. Since there are weapons that are just better than others you can directly use them.

Also the campaign esque mode is back, giving you a sort of narrative that involves a mix of objective types on the same map area, being a pretty neat idea. Its not played that often but I tend to find matches sometimes. Otherwise its just mostly the same, aside that you can now build fortifications on specific points that reward some points. Can sometimes help, depends on the area. Its ok.

That aside it doesn’t improve that much over battlefield 1, there is a reason why I still play it, as the setting got rid off some of the more unique aspects that game had and replaced them barely, you can still bayonet attack with a few weapons but its rather rare to see. Gas is obviously gone. New is a squad system where you can get points and order specific rewards, like artillery strikes or a vehicle as the squad leader. Bonus points are there when you follow /give orders and reviving squadmates without being a medic is now possible, in a slower animation. Good improvement.

There is a major issue in the multiplayer and that is the amount of hackers it got. And I am not saying just fishy wallhack maybes but rather fully fledged thermal scope 100-0 aimbotting guys. There is no way to kick them and I discovered a lot of them. This can ruin absolutely the experience. This is just straight unacceptable for a flagship title, especially even more since Dices last game completely flopped.

Also the core gameplay issue is still there, for being a videogame the kill time is way too low, or atleast for my preference. I don’t want to always die solely because someone saw me first, this is in world war 2 games due to the weapons low accuracy usually not a problem, but here all weapons function just like battlefield 1 with pin point accuracy. There is also an abundance of vehicles again, which are super hard to counter as always.

Compared to the previous game you never fight in a giant battle or airship or anything the like, the previous game does feel a lot more impressive.
[u]Story[/u]
The main storyline is just like in Battlefield 1 set in a variety of mini stories. I found this a lot more enjoyable than a long lasting story as these are more impactful and don’t tend to drag on a lot. Especially unique is the fact that you can play as a German which is rare in this type of shooter. The stories felt pretty neat, had each their own narrative that I actually enjoyed playing through. My only issue is that there isn't enough, its too short, I wanted more.

Also the controversial stuff, like having a lot of women etc. around is just mostly in the multiplayer. The single player story is pretty credible and doesn't paint a false picture like that. The opposite, you play as either a french foreign black soldier in France, which in itself is a credible story, or as a Norwegian female guerrilla warrior. Thats ok i think.

[u]Sound[/u]
My favourite aspect was the fact that people talk in their native language and have various calls and comment way much more often on the current events. You can give a variety of orders or commands that the characters will shout out. Additionally the guns sound very neat, bombs impactful (especially mortar fire) and the various vehicle sounds while being in them make immersion very easily.

[u]Graphics[/u]
Things aside the game runs pretty well and looks very good, not only are the textures pretty neat, but also the effects this game has. Especially when being under mortar fire. Your character can catch mud on his clothes and while laying in the dirt and looking around you can see your whole body taking up space and also moving around. Quite immersive.

[u]Conclusion/TL;DR[/u]
 While despite not really being my type of genre this game is pretty fun, especially considering how it improved some aspects of the previous game I disliked or liked. Campaign is short lived fun and multiplayer is still very active. The main reason to not get this game is because of the non existent anti cheat systems, the problem is too widespread to be in any way possible to overlook.

[h1] Battlefield™ V: A Thrilling World War II Shooter [/h1]

Overall Rating: ★★★★☆

Battlefield™ V, developed by DICE and published by Electronic Arts, takes players back to the era of World War II, delivering an immersive and intense first-person shooter experience. With its stunning visuals, realistic gameplay mechanics, and expansive multiplayer battles, Battlefield™ V offers an engaging and thrilling war gaming experience.

Graphics: ★★★★★
The graphics in Battlefield™ V are truly impressive, showcasing detailed environments, realistic character models, and breathtaking visual effects. The game's Frostbite engine brings the war-torn landscapes to life, creating a visually stunning and immersive experience that captures the chaos and intensity of World War II.

Gameplay: ★★★★☆
The gameplay in Battlefield™ V is fast-paced and action-packed. Players can choose from a variety of classes and engage in large-scale multiplayer battles, featuring infantry combat, vehicular warfare, and dynamic destruction. The game introduces new gameplay mechanics, such as fortifications and squad reinforcements, which add strategic depth to the matches.

Single Player: ★★★☆☆
While Battlefield™ V's single-player campaign offers several War Stories, providing unique perspectives from different theaters of World War II, the overall narrative may feel disjointed and lacks depth. However, the individual missions still showcase impressive set pieces, memorable moments, and engaging gameplay scenarios.

Multiplayer: ★★★★☆
The multiplayer mode is where Battlefield™ V truly shines. The Grand Operations mode allows players to participate in multi-day battles across multiple maps, each with specific objectives and gameplay dynamics. The cooperative Combined Arms mode offers intense squad-based missions, while the classic Conquest mode provides large-scale warfare and strategic gameplay.

Content and Progression: ★★★★☆
Battlefield™ V offers a variety of maps, weapons, vehicles, and customization options, allowing players to tailor their experience to their preferred playstyle. The game features a progression system that unlocks new gear and abilities as players earn experience points. Regular updates and additional content releases have also expanded the game's offerings over time.

Conclusion:
Battlefield™ V delivers an immersive and visually stunning World War II shooter experience. With its intense multiplayer battles, impressive graphics, and strategic gameplay mechanics, it offers hours of excitement for fans of the genre. While the single-player campaign may lack depth, the engaging multiplayer modes and ongoing content updates make Battlefield™ V a worthwhile addition to any shooter enthusiast's collection.

Hi! I purchased this game as part of a bundle with Battlefield 4 and Battlefield 1 at a fair price. It quickly became one of my favorite Battlefield games of all time. The gameplay is highly addictive, and it is not uncommon to spend over 100 hours immersed in this game. The weapon sounds are particularly impressive, although I am not sure if they accurately represent the real thing. The music also adds to the experience, perfectly capturing the WWII theme.

One of the standout features of Battlefield 5 is its stunning graphics and meticulous attention to detail. The visuals are truly impressive, effectively depicting both the horrors and grandeur of war. The meticulously designed environments and dynamic weather effects further enhance the immersion. The sound design is equally impressive, with realistic weapon sounds and explosions that contribute to the overall atmosphere.

However, the campaign mode in Battlefield 5 is not particularly good, and the game is primarily worth playing for its multiplayer experience.

I've also played Battlefield 1 and Battlefield 2042, and I must say that Battlefield 1 is my favorite, with Battlefield 5 coming in second place. Battlefield 1 offers a more challenging experience since it takes place in WWI with less advanced technology, requiring more effort to aim accurately. On the other hand, Battlefield 5 is set in WWII, where the technology and machinery are more modern. I highly recommend giving Battlefield 1 a try; it's definitely worth it.

In conclusion, Battlefield 5 is a good game, thanks to its stunning graphics, diverse gameplay options, and engaging multiplayer experience. Although the single-player component falls short, the multiplayer battles provide thrilling moments of intensity and cooperation. If you come across a discounted price for Battlefield 5, it's definitely worth considering adding it to your gaming library. It offers hours of immersive and action-packed gameplay.

Gameplay and Mechanics:
Battlefield V builds upon the successful formula of the Battlefield series, offering large-scale battles that combine infantry combat, vehicle warfare, and strategic objectives. The game features a variety of modes, including the iconic Conquest and Operations, as well as the cooperative Combined Arms and the battle royale-inspired Firestorm.

The gameplay mechanics in Battlefield V are polished and refined. The gunplay is satisfying, with a wide range of authentic weapons that each handle differently. The addition of fortifications allows players to build defenses and create tactical advantages on the battlefield. The inclusion of vehicles, such as tanks, planes, and transport vehicles, adds depth and variety to the gameplay, allowing for epic battles and strategic maneuvers.

The squad-based mechanics are a highlight of Battlefield V. The game encourages teamwork and coordination, with the ability to revive fallen teammates, provide ammunition, and cooperate on objectives. The squad play fosters a sense of camaraderie and reinforces the importance of strategic teamwork in achieving victory.

Visuals and Audio:
Battlefield V showcases stunning visuals that bring the war-torn environments to life. The game's attention to detail is commendable, with realistic weapon models, detailed character animations, and destructible environments that react dynamically to the chaos of battle. The graphical fidelity, coupled with realistic lighting and weather effects, contributes to the immersive and cinematic nature of the game.

The audio design in Battlefield V is top-notch, capturing the chaos and intensity of war. The sound of gunfire, explosions, and the thunderous roar of tanks and aircraft create a visceral audio landscape. The inclusion of authentic World War II-era music and voice acting further enhances the immersion and adds to the historical atmosphere.

Historical Accuracy and Representation:
Battlefield V strives for historical accuracy while also offering a diverse representation of soldiers and combatants during World War II. The game's single-player War Stories mode presents different perspectives and narratives, shedding light on lesser-known aspects of the war. The multiplayer experience features a variety of playable factions, including the British, Germans, Americans, and more, providing a broad representation of the conflict.

It is worth noting that Battlefield V takes certain liberties with historical accuracy to accommodate gameplay balance and variety. While this may disappoint purists seeking a strictly authentic experience, the game manages to strike a balance between historical accuracy and enjoyable gameplay.

Conclusion:
Battlefield V delivers an immersive and action-packed World War II experience. With its refined gameplay mechanics, stunning visuals, and attention to historical detail, the game captures the epic scale and intensity of war. The cooperative squad-based gameplay, coupled with a variety of modes and an emphasis on teamwork, ensures a dynamic and engaging multiplayer experience.

While some historical liberties are taken, Battlefield V successfully balances authenticity with enjoyable gameplay. The game's dedication to representing different perspectives and lesser-known narratives of the war adds depth and meaning to the experience.

Overall, Battlefield V stands as a worthy addition to the Battlefield series, offering a grand and authentic World War II experience that is both visually stunning and immersive. For fans of first-person shooters and military history enthusiasts, Battlefield V is a must-play.

I had a bunch of fun playing this battlefield but my recommendation roller coaster of game time brings me to a no. This was my first BF game back into the series of the newer ones with the last being BF3 on 360 back in the 2010 era. The first two sessions we played a couple months ago over about 3 hours was just fully of so many hackers on each server so we dropped the game. 
Came back and ran through the campaigns on hardcore a few months later to get my dollar out of it and they were actually decent. Nothing super crazy story wise but the missions we still decent, the game looks great, and the sound design was fireee if not the best part. After that we jumped back in multiplayer and started getting games with minimal to no hacking and it was actually super dope. The game is well balanced and the multiplayer maps were solid with a good variety across them. Squad play has a huge advantage if you can communicate with everyone. Sniping is extremely satisfying and the CQB gun fight on objectives is awesome and I still will never care to use vehicles in the BF series outside of transportation lol. Each of the 4 classes has an equal contribution to the game which keeps the meta freedom to any one and I think almost all guns are like that too which brings it down to preference. The weapon and character customization felt overwhelming at first but its actually very minimal which I enjoy. There are just a few standard attachments and a couple of gun traits to choose from, but just a spew of cosmetic stuff which served zero interest. The only thing I wish I got to try was the battle royal game type just so I could see what a BF take on BR would play like but no one plays it. 
So at this point the game was being a full recommendation on my list until you just get dumped on by hackers. The maps are big enough that half the hacks do not affect the entire map but the list of hacks is fried. Invincibility, super speed hacks, aim/wall/bullet noclip hacks(and combo that with tanks), fingerrrrrrr guuuuuuun 1 shot hack, or the most annoying wiping the entire lobby individual score/xp and just instakilling the whole lobby. I still had fun playing it and its not bad for avoiding/finding new servers with out hackers but these guys do not give an f about their game so I cannot promote them getting more money off this one.
hackers absolutely everywhere. fun game during its prime and it still is if you're lucky enough to find a hacker free server. but i don't recommend playing this now

Just like most online games, it's the community that stops me recommending this. Official servers are plagued with hackers and toxicity. No moderation at all. The community has created their own moderation tools for private servers (see BFV Robot) due to how severe the problem is. Aalthough this can have it's own issues (got incredibly lucky with a double headshot within the first 30 seconds of joining a server and was banned, but you can appeal this on the developers Discord).

Are all online shooters plagued with the same issue? Pretty much. If you pick this game up for less than $5, have 90GB+ hard drive space it takes up, and can deal with the crappy EA launcher being installed alongside it...grab it. If not, look to any other shooter.

Recently, in a battle in Rotterdam, an anonymous Allied soldier single-handedly repelled the German 22nd Infantry Division, who was responsible for the frontal attack. In a fierce battle that lasted for an hour, the 65th Infantry Division, which was responsible for the frontal attack, suffered heavy casualties, with a staggering reduction rate of 93%. According to the surviving German veteran, he only saw a floating gun in the air and didn't even see anyone, but in the midst of lightning, more than half of his team members were already dead or injured. Whether the secret genetic experiments in the Allied powers exist or not, rumors about the "Captain America" have long caused panic at the bottom of the German army. At present, the German Supreme Command is still discussing the issue of attacking the Netherlands. The Chief of Staff of the German Armed Forces Supreme Command, Kaitel, claimed that under his urging, German scientists have discovered that orphaned children who have lost their parents can easily be lured into a new generation of super warriors. They can tear apart tigers with their hands, and their eyes can see through grass and trees thousands of meters away, with a reaction power several hundred times that of ordinary people. In order to catch up with the progress of the war, the first batch of "Aryan Supermans" are being transported to the front line at full speed. We do not know whether Kettle's move was to appease the morale of the lower German army, or whether it was indeed the case. Perhaps in future battles, we can see Captain America fighting against Aryan Superman. But during the war of mutation and transformation, where should we ordinary soldiers go?

So much cheating. I have to second guess every dodgy interaction and it ruins the fun entirely. Sometimes you have a good game or five and its so much fun but then you have a whole day of maybe cheaters, maybe just good players who are level 12 of 500. I have no problem dying a lot. I can still have fun, but when spotted the entire game while in cover and getting instantly headshot out of nowhere with inaccurate guns it's just stupid. Very annoying, do not recommend. What games am I supposed to play? I feel like all games are shit at the moment. AAA games are full of cheaters or are only playable 2 years into release. Indie games get released in a borderline unplayable state as "early access" and stay that way for 3 years before hype gets lost so they never get finished. I need new hobbies. Fuck EA and DICE

Massive improvement in terms of gameplay in comparison to Battlefield 1's atrocious systems, sadly the huge potential that BFV had has been ruined by bad management and unsatisfactory post-launch support. Lack of good anti-cheat and team balancing has ultimately ruined what could have been easily the best entry in the franchise. Also, some questionable cosmetics.

I like the gameplay, but the game is unplayable on PC with all the hackers populating every single server you play on. I haven't been able to play a single day without facing at least two hackers.

Vehicles are also busted with tanks being able to have 360 degree vision and planes being able to orbit in space just shooting down rockets at people. People knowing the vehicle exploits just dominate servers.
